entry.title: Scheduling Background Jobs in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud: A Practical Guide
entry.content:
Step 1: Create the ABAP Class with Required Interfaces

You‚Äôll start by creating a class that contains the logic to be executed in the background.

Interfaces Implemented:

  • IF_OO_ADT_CLASSRUN: Allows testing the class directly in ADT.
  • IF_APJ_DT_EXEC_OBJECT: Defines job metadata and input parameters.
  • IF_APJ_RT_EXEC_OBJECT: Contains the actual logic to be executed in the background job.

Your class might look like this:

CLASS zcl_insert_sample_data DEFINITION
  PUBLIC
  FINAL
  CREATE PUBLIC.

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    INTERFACES: if_oo_adt_classrun,
                if_apj_dt_exec_object,
                if_apj_rt_exec_object.

  PRIVATE SECTION.
    METHODS: insert_sample_data.
ENDCLASS.
METHOD if_apj_rt_exec_object~execute.
* " This is the method that will be called by the background job
DATA: application_log           TYPE REF TO if_bali_log,
          application_log_free_text TYPE REF TO if_bali_free_text_setter.
   TRY.
   insert_sample_data( ).
application_log = cl_bali_log=>create_with_header(
                               header = cl_bali_header_setter=>create( object = 'XYZ' " Use your custom log object/subobject
                                                                       subobject = 'INSERT' ) ).
        application_log_free_text = cl_bali_free_text_setter=>create(
                                        severity = if_bali_constants=>c_severity_information " Or c_severity_success
                                        text     = 'Sample data inserted successfully.' ).

        application_log->add_item( item = application_log_free_text ).
        cl_bali_log_db=>get_instance( )->save_log(
            log                        = application_log
            assign_to_current_appl_job = abap_true  ).

      CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_error).
        " Log the error message to the Application Log
*        application_log = cl_bali_log=>create_with_header(
*                               header = cl_bali_header_setter=>create( object = 'ZSAMPLE_DATA'
*                                                                       subobject = 'INSERT' ) ).
*        application_log_free_text = cl_bali_free_text_setter=>create(
*                                        severity = if_bali_constants=>c_severity_error
*                                        text     = |Error inserting data: { lx_error->get_text( ) }| ).
*
*        application_log->add_item( item = application_log_free_text ).
*        cl_bali_log_db=>get_instance( )->save_log(
*            log                        = application_log
*            assign_to_current_appl_job = abap_true  ).

        " Re-raise the exception to signal job failure to the framework
*        RAISE EXCEPTION TYPE cx_apj_rt_exec_object
*          EXPORTING
*            previous = lx_error.

    ENDTRY.

This class inserts sample data into a custom table and logs the result using CL_BALI_LOG.

üìò Step 2: Create a Job Catalog Entry in ADT

Once your class is ready, the next step is to register it in the Job Catalog using ADT.

How to do it:

  1. In ADT, go to the Project Explorer.
  2. Right-click on your package ‚Üí New ‚Üí Other ‚Üí ABAP Repository Object.
  3. Search for Job Catalog Entry.
  4. Provide:
    • Catalog ID: e.g., ZZ1_INSER_DATA
    • Description: e.g., Insert Sample Titles
    • Execution Class: ZCL_INSERT_SAMPLE_DATA
  5. Save and activate.

 

This step makes your class available for job templates.

üßæ Step 3: Create a Job Template in ADT

Now, create a Job Template based on the catalog entry.

Steps:

  1. In ADT, right-click your package ‚Üí New ‚Üí Other ‚Üí ABAP Repository Object.
  2. Search for Job Template.
  3. Provide:
    • Template ID: ZZ1_JOB
    • Description: Insert Sample Titles
    • Job Catalog Entry: ZZ1_INSER_DATA
  4. If your class uses parameters, map them here.
  5. Save and activate.

 

This template will be used in the Fiori app to schedule the job.

üåê Step 4: Create an Application Job Template in Fiori

Now switch to the Fiori Launchpad.

Steps:

  1. Open the "Manage Application Job Templates" app.
  2. Click Create.
  3. Fill in:
    • Template Name: e.g., Insert Sample Titles
    • Job Template ID: ZZ1_JOB (from ADT)
    • Job Catalog ID: ZZ1_INSER_DATA
  4. Save and activate.

This step makes the job template available for end users.

Step 5: Schedule the Job in Fiori

Finally, schedule the job using the Fiori app.

Steps:

  1. Open the "Schedule Application Jobs" app.
  2. Click Create.
  3. Select your Application Job Template.
  4. Set:
    • Start Time: Immediate or scheduled
    • Recurrence: One-time or recurring
  5. Click Schedule.

üßæ Application Logging

Your class uses CL_BALI_LOG to write messages to the application log. This is essential for monitoring and debugging.

Benefits:

  • Structured logging with severity levels.
  • Integration with job monitoring tools.
  • Easy to trace job execution history.

entry.title: Key User Custom Fields: How to add a custom field to a specific Fiori UI section
entry.content:
Have you ever created a key user custom field and wanted to display it in a standard SAP Fiori UI, but didn't know which OData service entity to enable to make the field available in the field list offered by Fiori Runtime Adaptation?

If your answer is yes, then this blog post is just for you. It explains how you can find out the respective OData service entity manually (called Variant 1: Manual way). It also explains a much simpler alternative how to enable the OData service entity for the given field using the integration between Fiori Runtime Adaptation and the key user custom field tool (called Variant 2: Automatic way).

Variant 1: Manual way

The first step is to identify which OData service entity provides the data for the UI section in the Fiori UI of the SAP standard application. Once you have this information, you can enable the custom field in the Custom Fields app for the specified OData service entity. This action makes the custom field available in the list of fields within Fiori Runtime Adaptation.

Let‚Äôs assume that you created a custom field named ‚ÄúPriority‚Äù on the business context SD_SALESDOC, and you want to expose this custom field in the Fiori app Manage Sales Orders - Version 2 (Fiori app ID F3893). You want to place the field in the ‚ÄúBasic Data‚Äù section of the ‚ÄúGeneral Information‚Äù section of the Sales Order UI (the location is marked with a red cross within the screenshot).

You want to place the custom field here

First, you need to find out which OData service entity provides the data for the UI section where you want to place the field.
You can find this out by adhering to the following steps:

  1. Open the Fiori app Manage Sales Orders - Version 2 and navigate to the respective screen within this UI (in our case, it‚Äôs the detail screen of the sales order)
  2. Use the key combination CTRL + SHIFT + ALT + S. A Fiori Diagnostics dialog pops up
  3. Within the dialog UI, open the Control Tree section
  4. Go back to the ‚ÄúGeneral Information Basic Data‚Äù section of the Sales Order UI and press CTRL + ALT + SHIFT. Then, pick the UI section or field you are interested in within the application UI. In our example, we used the ‚ÄúOrder Reason‚Äù field (make sure that you select the field and not its label). The control in the control tree representing this field is selected
  5. Now, you can select the ‚ÄúBinding Info‚Äù tab shown on the right side of the control tree screen. In the ‚Äúpath‚Äù field, you‚Äôll see the name ‚ÄúSalesOrderManage‚Äù of the OData entity where the field is bound against (see subsequent screenshot).

Find the OData entity set name within the binding information for a field

Equipped with this information, you can now navigate back to the custom fields tool. Go to the details screen of your custom field (in our example, it‚Äôs the field ‚ÄúYY1_Priority‚Äù) and open the ‚ÄúUser Interfaces‚Äù tab. Enter ‚ÄúSalesOrderManage‚Äù in the search bar.
This leads to the following result:

Find the OData entity set name within the binding information for a field

In the ‚ÄúData Source‚Äù column, you‚Äôll now see the ‚ÄúSalesOrderManageType‚Äù data source. This corresponds to the entity set name ‚ÄúSalesOrderManage‚Äù. The different suffix ‚ÄúType‚Äù is used because in the Custom Fields app, the entity type is shown instead of the entity set name.

There may be cases where several OData services share the same OData entity set name, and all of them support exposing the respective custom fields. In this case, you can find out which of the search results is the right one by comparing the description of the OData service entry in the custom fields tool with the info you see in the ‚ÄúInherited from‚Äù field within the Binding Infos tab of the control tree. Since only the technical name and not the description is shown, it won‚Äôt match exactly, but in a lot of cases it‚Äôs quite similar.

Alternatively, you can compare the names in the Custom Fields app with the ones contained in the Configuration section within Implementation Information tab of the relevant Fiori app in SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library:

OData service(s) related to Fiori app

Clicking ‚ÄúEnable Usage‚Äù and publishing the field makes it available for the respective UI section using Runtime Adaptation.

Variant 2: Automatic way

Please note that you can also use the integration between UI Runtime Adaptation and the custom fields tool to make this process easier:

  1. Open the Fiori app Manage Sales Orders - Version 2 and navigate to the respective screen within this UI (in our case, it‚Äôs the detail screen of the sales order)
  2. Switch into Runtime Adaptation mode by selecting the ‚ÄúAdapt UI‚Äù option in the drop-down menu. You can get to the drop-down menu by clicking on your avatar on the top right icon representing your user
  3. Select the field or section you‚Äôre interested in. Right-click to select ‚Äú+ Add: Field‚Äù from the drop-down menu
  4. A popup displays all available fields and business contexts. Mostly, there is only one ‚Äì in our case it‚Äôs ‚ÄúSales: Sales Document‚Äù. A ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù option on the right top of the popup allows you to select the ‚ÄúCustom Field‚Äù sub-option. Clicking ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù you‚Äôll be navigated to the Custom Fields app. The Custom Fields app now knows from which UI section you‚Äôve navigated to it. It also understands which OData service entity was bound against the UI section from where you came from. The business context is also taken as pre-selection information.
  5. If you create a new custom field, then the respective OData service entity is enabled automatically. If you navigate to the details of an already existing field, you‚Äôll get a popup asking whether you want to enable the respective OData service entity you are coming from. When you select ‚ÄúYes‚Äù, this will be done automatically for you (see screenshot below):

Popup allowing you to ‚Äúautomatically‚Äù enable the respective OData service entity for the given custom field

In case you select ‚ÄúNo‚Äù, when you navigate back to the ‚ÄúUser Interfaces‚Äù tab, the mentioned OData service and the OData entity will be marked with a blue bar to make it easier for you to find (see screenshot below).

OData service and OData entity marked in the Custom Fields app

Now, you‚Äôre done, and you‚Äôve found out which OData service entity to enable to make the field available in the field list offered by Fiori Runtime Adaptation.

Feedback, Comments, or Questions:

You‚Äôre cordially invited to provide them in the comments section below. Also, please follow my profile to get updates when I publish more posts on these topics.
Also feel invited to post and answer questions here (https://answers.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26) and read other posts on the topic (https://blogs.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26/).

I want to thank Yasmina van Rooij  and Karsten Schaser for their extremely helpful contributions.

Other related blog posts and other infos:

  • https://blogs.sap.com/2022/06/23/easily-manage-your-key-user-adaptations-with-sapui5-flexibility/
  • SAP Help - Adapt UI
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-screen-personas-how-to-position-key-user-custom-fields-exactly-where/ba-p/13553723

entry.title: Help influence the next AI Features for SAP My Home on SAP S/4HANA Public Edition
entry.content:
SAP My Home is the starting point for SAP S/4HANA. It contains all your to-do items, news feeds, apps, and insights tiles and cards.  SAP Business AI delivers embedded AI capabilities that enhance user productivity through contextual to-do alerts, role-based application recommendations, and natural language-driven card creation. Additionally, Joule provides an AI-powered conversational interface to streamline information retrieval and support business operations.

We‚Äôre continuing to expand the capabilities of SAP My Home and invite your feedback on two usability-focused enhancements. To support this, we‚Äôre launching two new Customer Engagement Initiatives (CEIs), open to customers and partners using  SAP Cloud ERP (SAP S/4HANA Public Edition)

This initiative focuses on:

  • AI-assisted smart solution for situations in My Home, which provides resolution suggestions directly on the homepage for faster task completion (https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#campaign/3931)
  • AI-assisted error explanation for SAP Fiori elements-based applications, intelligent suggestions to help users fix system errors quickly and intuitively (https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#campaign/3929)

These innovations aim to reduce training time, boost productivity, and make the SAP experience more seamless and intelligent.

SAP Products in Focus

  • SAP My Home page
  • SAP Fiori apps using the SAP Fiori elements framework

Why Join?

  • Get early access to upcoming innovations
  • Help shape tools that better fit your day-to-day needs
  • Collaborate with SAP designers, developers, and product experts
  • Influence real product enhancements with your insight

Your  input now will help improve the user experience of SAP Cloud ERP, helping other customers save time and simplify business processes.

entry.title: Collective Invoicing for Service Orders Part 2: Working with Custom Fields
entry.content:
In my previous blog post, I explained the fundamentals of setting up copying control for collective invoicing in service documents. In this blog post, we will be taking a look at further steps required in case you are additionally using custom fields in your service order, for which the business scenario to copy these to billing documents have enabled, as the custom fields will act as a billing document split criteria. To suppress this, you will need to create a custom logic implementation (extension point SD_BIL_DATA_TRANSFER), in which you can add the following code:

 

  • Create a custom logic implementation for the extension point ‚ÄúSD_BIL_DATA_TRANSFER‚Äù

In the code editor, add the following code:

*   Mandatory step for all implementations:

*   Copy the importing parameters to the changing parameters.

    MOVE-CORRESPONDING bil_doc TO bil_doc_res.

    MOVE-CORRESPONDING bil_doc_item TO bil_doc_item_res.

    MOVE-CORRESPONDING bil_doc_item_contr TO bil_doc_item_contr_res.


*Clear value of custom field Ticket number, as this shouldn't be used as a split criterion for billing'

CLEAR bil_doc_res-<YY1_CUSTOM_FIELD_NAME>.
  • Define Custom Routine (SSCUI 102865):

 

In the assign enhancement IDs view, select the following. The enhancement identifier should match the filter value of the custom logic implementation from Step 1.

 

In the copy control configuration activities (from the previous blog post), for all the relevant item categories, maintain the custom routine number created in Step 2)

 

 

After this, you can test the creation of a billing document from multiple service orders to create one collective invoice, wherein the differing values of the custom field from multiple service orders will no longer act as a billing split criterion

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition seamless integration with Shopify - Complete Setup and Demo Guide
entry.content:
Tired of Juggling Data Between SAP and Shopify? We‚Äôve Got You Covered!

Managing data and business processes across SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and Shopify can often be a challenging and time-consuming task ‚Äî especially when done manually or through custom-built integrations. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre excited to introduce a ready-to-use integration package powered by SAP Integration Suite, built to simplify and streamline your operations.

Designed specifically for B2C commerce scenarios, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify integration package ensures:

  • Seamless data synchronization between SAP and Shopify
  • Automated workflows for key business processes
  • A reduction in manual tasks and potential errors

In this blog, we‚Äôll start with a high-level overview of what the integration offers. Then, we‚Äôll walk you through a step-by-step guide to setting up the package ‚Äî so you can get your systems connected and running efficiently with minimal effort.

Note : SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify integration package accelerator isn‚Äôt just limited to B2C. Partners can extend the integration to support B2B use cases as well, tailoring it to fit the needs of more complex business models. The package is built with extensibility in mind, so partners can enhance it further to accommodate specific business requirements or tailor it to specific industry needs.

Overview of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify Integration Package:

SAP provides a variety of pre-built integration accelerators via the SAP Integration Suite, all accessible through the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. Among these, we‚Äôve developed a dedicated Shopify integration accelerator that enables a seamless connection between your Shopify storefront and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

The  SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify integration package ensures real-time data consistency across both platforms by synchronizing key business objects such as:

  •  üõí  Product information
  •  üì¶  Inventory levels/Product Stock
  • üí≤Product Prices & Discounts 
  •  üë§  Customer information

By automating critical business processes like order creation, cancellations, and returns, the integration reduces manual effort, minimizes errors, and increases operational efficiency. It also synchronizes shipping and delivery details, helping you provide accurate and timely updates to customers ‚Äî a key to delivering a superior B2C customer experience.

The Shopify Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud package is designed to integrate key end-to-end business processes between SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and Shopify, enabling smooth, automated data flow and operational consistency across both platforms.

The following core business processes are supported out of the box:

üì¶ From SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Shopify:

  • ‚úÖ Replicate Products ‚Äì Ensure accurate and up-to-date product information is reflected in your Shopify storefront.
  • üìä Replicate Product Stock ‚Äì Keep inventory levels in sync to avoid overselling or stockouts.
  • üí≤ Replicate Product Prices & Discounts ‚Äì Automatically update pricing and promotional details in Shopify.
  • üöö Replicate Delivery Details ‚Äì Provide timely and accurate shipping information to your customers via Shopify.

üõíFrom Shopify to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition:

  • üë• Replicate B2C Customers ‚Äì Capture and transfer customer data from Shopify to SAP, enabling centralized customer management.
  • üßæReplicate Orders ‚Äì Seamlessly transfer incoming sales orders into SAP for fulfillment and processing.
  • ‚ùå Replicate Order Cancellations ‚Äì Reflect cancelled orders in SAP for proper stock and financial reconciliation.
  • üîÅ Replicate Order Returns ‚Äì Automatically push return details from Shopify into SAP to streamline reverse logistics.

Together, these integration flows deliver a robust, automated B2C commerce experience, reducing manual interventions and ensuring your front-end and back-end systems remain in sync.

üöÄ How to Set Up the ‚ÄúShopify Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud  Public Edition‚Äù Package

Integrating Shopify with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is now easier than ever ‚Äî thanks to the pre-built accelerator available on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. This step-by-step guide will help you configure and deploy the integration package using SAP Integration Suite, so your systems can work together seamlessly.

‚úÖPrerequisites

Before you begin, ensure you have the following:

  • üîë  An SAP Partner Account with access to SAP Integration Suite (via SAP BTP ‚Äì Business Technology Platform).
  • üßæ Access to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • üõç  A Shopify Partner or Merchant Account.
  • üìò  Basic knowledge of SAP BTP, Integration Suite and Shopify. 
  • üåê  Access to SAP Business Accelerator Hub.
  • üìòDetailed Configure Guide - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify Configuration Guide in SAP Business Accelerator Hub

 üõ†Ô∏è  Step 1: Set Up SAP Integration Suite instance using SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) account.

  1. Log in to SAP BTP Cockpit.
  2. Create a Subaccount and enable Integration Suite:
    • Navigate to your Global Account > Subaccount.
    • Create or open an Integration Suite instance.
    • Assign relevant entitlements and Assign relevant roles
    • Use the Booster Enable Integration Suite to automate setup or configure manually
    • for more details refer to sap help documentation SAP Integration Suite | SAP Help Portal

üì¶ Step 2: Import the Shopify Adapter Package into SAP Integration Suite

  1. Goto SAP Integration Suite instance
  2. Go to Discover tab.
  3. Search for ‚ÄúShopify Adapter for SAP Integration Suite‚Äù.
  • Click ‚ÄúCopy‚Äù to add / move the package to your Design workspace.

  • To Configure Shopify Adapter Installation - Installing the Shopify Adapter is a prerequisite to use the Integration Content. For adapter installation, refer to the ‚ÄúShopify Adapter Guide‚Äù and to the ‚ÄúShopify Adapter and Plug-in Installation Guide‚Äù and also refer to more details refer to section "Shopify Adapter Installation" in configuration guide SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify Configuration Guide in SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

üîÑStep 3: Configure Shopify iFlows (Integration Flows) with API access relevant details.

  1. Go to Design > Integrations in the Integration Suite.
  2. Open the imported Shopify Integration Package.
  3. Select a relevant iFlow (e.g., Replicate Orders from Shopify to SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition).
  4. Configure the necessary Externalized Parameters and Connections, referencing the detailed documentation for each Integration Flow.
  5. To Configuration in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - the mandatory configurations which need to be performed in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition before you can start implementing the configuration for Shopify API and configuring the Integration Content in SAP Integration Suite and for more details refer to section "Configuration in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition" in configuration guide SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify Configuration Guide in SAP Business Accelerator Hub.
  6. Sample configuration shown below.

      Shopify Receiver Adapter Connection Configuration

  • Shopify Base Url: https://<yourshop>.myshopify.com/
  • Shopify Secure Parameter: The name of the Shopify access token secure parameter 

       SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Receiver Adapter Connection Configuration

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Base Url: https://<your-sap-s4-hana-instance-id>-api.s4hana.cloud.sap
  • Credential Name: The name of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition secure parameter 

üß© Example Integration Flows:

  • Shopify ‚ûú SAP S4HANA Public Cloud Edition : Customer Replication, New Orders, Order Cancellations & Returns
  • SAP S4HANA Public Cloud Edition ‚ûú Shopify: Products, Inventory Synchronization, Stock Availability, Delivery Status

üöÄStep 4: Deploy and Test the Integration Package in Integration Suite

  1. Deploy selected iFlows from your Design workspace.
  2. Monitor from Monitor > Integrations > Message Processing Logs.
  3. Perform test transactions: for more details refer to Demo section in the blog
    • Place a test order in Shopify.
    • Monitor the message logs and confirm data replication in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Sales Orders, Business Partners, Product Catalog

üîß Extend or Customize the Package (Optional)

As a partner you can extend or tailor the integration through:

  • Customer Exits to plug-in your custom integration flows (Pre Exits and Post Exits in Intergration Flows)
  • Copy and modify the integration content.
  • Groovy scripts to customize payload mappings.
  • Content Modifiers to apply business logic.
  • Enhanced error handling and alerting.

 üí° Partner Tips & Monetization Opportunities

As an SAP Partner, you can:

  • üí° Extend the integration flows and Build new integration flows using SAP Shopify adapte
  • üìú  Demo your solution with real-time order sync and inventory updates, build a demo to show real-time sync between Shopify and SAP with custom business case.
  • üß∞ Buildc Multi-Tenant Integration Templates for reuse across customers.
  • üß† Leverage SAP Integration Advisor for intelligent mapping.
  • üí°  Add your branding, services, or vertical-specific enhancements.

High Level Demo Flow to showcase Order processing along with Master data replication.

  • Step 1 : View the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify integration package in Integration Suite
  • Step 2: Show product in SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION  (to be replicated to shopify)
  • Step 3: Start replication of product in integration suite
  • Step 4: Show replicated product in Shopify and add picture and select the sales channel to be online store and activate the product
  • Step 5: Log into shopify as customer and browse through existing products
  • Step 6: Select the product replicated from SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION and add to basket
  • Step 7: Enter the relevant details like payment and create order
  • Step 8: Check the order created in shopify
  • Step 9: Replicate the order from shopify to SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION
  • Step 10: Log into SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION as internal_sales_rep and look for ‚ÄúManage Sales Order Version 2‚Äù app and open the sales order and change the order date to todays date (both in header and item level) and Save sales order
  • Step 11: Log into SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION as shipping_specialist and open app ‚ÄúCreate outbound delivery with order reference‚Äù
  • Step 12: Enter shipping point and enter the sales order and shipping date as todays date and save , note down the Outbound Delivery ID
  • Step 13: Open app ‚Äúpick outbound delivery‚Äù and enter Outbound Delivery ID and enter Actual GI Date DD/MM/YYYY (valid date, example 07/01/2025) , enter picking quantity as 1 and save
  • Step 14 : Click on Post GI and status of Outbound Delivery picking changes to Completely Processed. Note : show the SO Process flow of created order in SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION
  • Step 15 : Replicate the Outbound delivery from SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION public to Shopify .
  • Step 16: Open sales order in Shopify and show the OD created in SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION reflected in metadata fields of Sales order and status of Sales Order is changed to fulfilled.

Detailed Demo steps:

Shopify Demo systems include the following systems - Integration Suite Tenant [along with BTP Sub-Account), SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Shopify Admin Portal, Shopify Customer Portal

Step 1:  Access the  Integration Suite tenant and view ‚ÄúSAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify‚Äù integration package

  • Open Integration Suite
  • Navigate to ‚ÄúDiscover‚Äù -> ‚ÄúIntegration‚Äù
  • Search for integration Package ‚ÄúSAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify‚Äù  , view the integration flows and details.          

Step 2: Access to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition System to show the replicating product master

  • Access system using URL SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system as Product Master Specialist
  • Login with user = prodmaster_specialist
  • Launch the App : ‚ÄúManage Product Master Data‚Äù  and search for Product ID  (sample product ID - TG11_PH_CW12)
  • Note: in the demo product replication integration flow we are replicating only one product with product ID (sample product ID - TG11_PH_CW12) and user could decide to replicate all products / sub-set of products, based on specific functional requirements.

Step 3: Start replication of product in Integration Suite

  • Open Integration Suite
  • Navigate to Discover -> Integration (only first time)
  • Search for integration Package ‚ÄúSAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify‚Äù  , open the integration package -> copy the package
  • Navigate to Design -> Integration and API‚Äôs
  • Search for integration Package ‚ÄúSAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify‚Äù  ,
  • Navigate to ‚Äúartifacts‚Äù and search for integration package ‚ÄúReplicate Products from SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Shopify‚Äù
  • Deploy the integration flow ‚ÄúReplicate Products from SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Shopify‚Äù
    • To deploy => click on the ‚Äú3 dots‚Äù of integration package and select ‚Äúdeploy‚Äù
    • Deploy would start the product replication from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Shopify      

Step 4: Show replicated product in Shopify and add picture and select the sales channel to be online store and activate the product

  • Login using URL : Shopify 
  • Navigate to ‚ÄúProducts‚Äù
  • Check and prepare the product for selling to customer
    • Check the product is replicated
    • Add the picture to publish (click on ‚ÄúMedia‚Äù and click on ‚Äú+‚Äù and select the relevant picture‚Äù
  • Add the sales channel as online store ( click on ‚ÄúManage‚Äù in ‚ÄúPublishing‚Äù section, in the popup select ‚Äúonline store‚Äù  and click on ‚Äúinclude‚Äù and click on ‚Äúdone‚Äù )
  • Set the status of the product to be ‚ÄúActive‚Äù and ‚ÄúSave‚Äù the product
  • Note: for the product to be visible for customer in shopify portal for purchasing , the status must be set to ‚ÄúActive‚Äù and sales channel to be set to ‚Äúonline store‚Äù.      

Step 5: login to shopify as customer and browse through existing products

Step 6: select the product replicated from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and add to basket

  • Purchase the product (sample product ID - TG11_PH_CW12)
  • Select the product from catalog
  • Click on ‚ÄúAdd to Cart‚Äù and click on ‚ÄúCheckout‚Äù
  • Account and ShipTo address would be filled automatically with the logged in user details

Step 7: enter the relevant details like payment and create order

  • Enter the Credit Card Details : Card Number, Expiration Date, Security Code
  • Click on ‚ÄúPay Now‚Äù  , order would be placed         

Step 8: check the order created in shopify

  • Navigate to ‚ÄúOrders‚Äù
  • Check the order created with fulfillment status ‚ÄúUnfulfilled‚Äù , note down the ‚ÄúSAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Order ID‚Äù  , order ID would be used to search order created in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system      

Step 9: replicate the order from shopify to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

  • Open Integration Suite
  • Navigate to Design -> Integration and API‚Äôs
  • Search for integration Package ‚ÄúSAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify‚Äù  , open the integration package -> navigate to Artifacts , search for artifact ‚ÄúReplicate Orders from Shopify to SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition‚Äù
  • Deploy the integration flow ‚ÄúReplicate Products from SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Shopify‚Äù
  • Replication of orders in status Unfulfilled would be moved to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition .
  • Note: to check the status of replication by navigating to ‚ÄúMonitor‚Äù => ‚ÄúIntegration and API‚Äôs‚Äù , check for ‚Äúlogs‚Äù      

Step 10: Log into SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system as Sales Representative

  • open for ‚ÄúManage Sales Order Version 2‚Äù app
  • open the sales order and change the ‚ÄúRequested Delivery Date‚Äù to todays date (both in header and item level) and Save sales order
  • Note: delivery date to be changed to today‚Äôs date, since user want to complete the delivery of the order today by creating outbound delivery today.       
     

Step 11: Log into SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition as Delivery shipping specialist and complete the delivery of Order

  • open for ‚ÄúCreate outbound delivery with order reference‚Äù app

Step 12: Enter the key details like Shipping Point and Sales Order ...

  • enter shipping point sample as 3810 (select shipping point relevant for your use-case) and enter the sales order ID create earlier and Selection Date would be defaulted to todays date
  • click on ‚Äúcontinue‚Äù and click on ‚Äúsave‚Äù
  • note down the outbound delivery ID

Step 13: Delivery shipping specialist will pic the outbound delivery

  • open app ‚Äúpick outbound delivery‚Äù and enter ‚ÄúDelivery‚Äù id and enter ‚ÄúActual GI Date DD/MM/YYYY (valid date, example 07/01/2025) , enter ‚Äúpicking quantity‚Äù as 1 and click on ‚Äúsave‚Äù         

Step 14 : Delivery shipping specialist will Post Goods Issue for the corresponding outbound delivery

  • click on ‚ÄúPost GI‚Äù and status of Outbound Delivery picking changes to ‚ÄúCompletely Processed‚Äù.      

Note : show the Sales Order ‚ÄúProcess flow‚Äù of created order in SAP S/4HANA Cloud  Public Edition for the corresponding order, the process flow gives visual representation of business entities created in the system (Order, Outbound Delivery, Invoice ‚Ä¶)

Step 15 : replicate the Outbound delivery from S4 public to Shopify .

  • Open Integration Suite
  • Navigate to Design -> Integration and API‚Äôs
  • Search for integration Package ‚ÄúSAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify‚Äù  , open the integration package -> navigate to Artifacts , search for artifact ‚ÄúReplicate Orders from Shopify to SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition‚Äù
  • Deploy the integration flow ‚ÄúReplicate Delivery Details from SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Shopify‚Äù
  • Replication of outbound delivery from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system would be moved to Shopify and corresponding Order status would updated to ‚Äúfulfilled‚Äù in Shopify
  • Note: to check the status of replication by navigating to ‚ÄúMonitor‚Äù => ‚ÄúIntegration and API‚Äôs‚Äù , check for ‚Äúlogs‚Äù         

Step 16: open sales order in shopify and check the  status of Order, it should be changed from ‚ÄúUnfullfilled‚Äù to ‚Äúfulfilled‚Äù

  • Navigate to ‚ÄúOrders‚Äù
  • With the successfully delivery , the order should be fulfilled and order status should be ‚ÄúFulfilled‚Äù , note the fields ‚ÄúSAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Order ID‚Äù  and ‚ÄúSAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Outbound Deliveries‚Äù  in order would be copied from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system          

The above steps completes the High Level Demo Flow which showcase the order processing along with product master data replication.

Note: The  SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify integration package covers Order Returns and Order Cancellation business scenarios along with Order Processing, please feel free to explore the other business process like Order Returns and Order Cancellation .

entry.title: Controlling, Scheduling, and Costing of Production Using Custom Fields in Routing Based on AVC
entry.content:
Business Requirement 

Company X wants to calculate the production cost based on the variant selected when placing an order for a product. 

Before Company X can quote a price to its customer, it would like to know the correct cost to achieve the right profit margin. The cost calculation should occur as soon as the order is received, and well before actual production begins.

Company X applies a multiplier to the standard cost of operations, which varies depending on the product's configuration. They want to execute the process in their SAP Cloud ERP.

Solution at high level
This solution will focus on calculating the production cost based on the configuration and making it visible at the sales order. It doesn't deal with sales order processes as a whole.
The multiplier that Company X uses is created as a custom field (called YY1_price_factor) in Production Routing.

Key Steps in the Solution

  1. Creating Custom Field
  2. Setting Up Configurable Material
  3. Integrating Workcenter Formula
  4. Setting Object Dependency and Characteristics
  5. Executing Business Processes

Creating Custom Fields

Company X uses a custom field, YY1_price_factor, within Production Routing. This field is set up using the Key User Extensibility's Custom Field App, under the Business Context: Manufacturing Bill of Operations Operation. The custom field is crucial for linking production routing operations to sales orders.

a. Choose Add Field in the Custom Fields app.The custom field YY1_price_factor is created for production routing operations.

b. Enable the business scenario Routing to Production Order on Operation Level for the custom field YY1_price_factor.

c. Optional: Enable the GUI in the User Interface tab if you wish to see the fields in the UI.

 

Setting Up Configurable Material

a. Set the configurable material as described. The configurable material CM-MLFL-KM-VXX is associated with class AVC_CL_COMMON_VXX of class type 300. Characteristics such as AVC_CR_COUNTERWEIGHT_VXX or AVC_CR_FORKLIFT_VXX are used to execute sales order variant configurations.

b. Select the UsedfVarConfig checkbox.

 

Integrating Workcenter (WKC) Formula 

a. Map the custom field YY1_price_factor to the WKC formula parameter AZMDB1 in the Define Parameters activity. In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the configuration activities.

For more information, see also Configuration Environment of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

b. Create a WKC formula where the SAP standard parameter SAP_01 is multiplied by ZMDB1 to calculate costs in the Define Formulas for Work Centers activity. In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the configuration activities. 

For more details, see Step-by-Step Guide to Setting Up Custom Fields in Work Center Formula Parameters.

For more details on Work Center Formula, see the blog Controlling and Scheduling the Production Using the Work Center Formula Parameter.

Setting Object Dependency and Characteristics

To utilize YY1_price_factor in object dependency, it is referenced to the characteristic AVC_CR_PRICEFACTOR_VXX. This characteristic is calculated using a procedure in production routing, ensuring accurate cost calculations based on configuration changes.

a. Create characteristics AVC_CR_PRICEFACTOR_VXX using the Manage Characteristics app.

b. Reference the characteristic to the PLPO table with the field name YY1_price_factor_PPO in the Addnl data tab.

c. Assign characteristic AVC_CR_PRICEFACTOR_VXX to class AVC_CL_COMMON_VXX using the  Manage Classes app.

d. Assign the class AVC_CL_COMMON_VXX to the configured material in Manage Product Master Data.

e. Create a global procedure with the characteristics AVC_CR_PRICEFACTOR_VXX in production routing.

f. Maintain dependency with type Procedure.

g. Enter the formula in the Dependency Editor.

Executing Business Processes

Sales Order Impact

When a sales order is created for CM-MLFL-KM-VXX, the calculated cost and profit margin are displayed. Changes in configuration, such as altering the counterweight from 2,000 kg to 5,000 kg, dynamically adjust the costing and profit margin.

a. Set the counterweight to 2,000 kg in Variant Configuration.

The profit margin is calculated for 2,000 kgs. 

This solution focuses on calculating the production cost based on the configuration and displaying it on the sales order. It doesn't deal with sales order processes as a whole. The multiplier that Company X uses is created as a custom field (called YY1_price_factor) in Production Routing.

b. Set the counterweight to 5,000 kgs in Variant Configuration.The profit margin is calculated for 5,000 kgs. 

Production Order Impact

In production orders, the custom field price_factor reflects changes in sales order configurations. For instance, changing the counterweight from 2,000 kg to 5,000 kg adjusts the price_factor from 2 to 5, demonstrating the direct impact of configuration changes on production costs.

a. Search for the material CM-MLFL-KM-VXX in the Manage Material Coverage app.

 

b. Choose Start MRP Run to create a planned order.

c. Convert the planned order to a production order. Once the production order is created, check the User Field price_factor in Operations. For counterweight 2,000 KG, the price_factor is 2.

d. Now, if this counterweight is changed in the sales order variant config to 5,000 KG, and the MRP run happens again to create the production order in the same way as described above. The price_factor changes to 5 as shown below.

By integrating custom fields and formulas, Company X provides a streamlined approach to managing production costs, enhancing visibility and accuracy in sales orders and production processes. This solution empowers businesses to make informed decisions and optimize their operations.

entry.title: Developing a Customized AR Aging Analysis Report in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - Part 1
entry.content:
Introduction:

Hello everyone, Myself Sriram Balaji, I am currently working as an SAP FICO Consultant. Last year, I got an opportunity to work in SAP Public Cloud Greenfield Implementation Project. During the ‚ÄúFIT to Standard‚Äù and ‚ÄúUAT‚Äù sessions, we have demonstrated the SAP standard Customer / Supplier Aging Analysis Report to the client but they are not satisfied with the standard aging report. They required a tailored Aging Analysis Report for Customer and Supplier, one that aligned perfectly with their unique operational requirements. This experience highlighted the importance of understanding client expectations beyond standard functionalities and fueled my journey into customizing SAP solutions in the Public Cloud.

In this blog, we are going to explore how we can develop Customized Customer (AR) Aging Analysis Report using the ‚ÄúKey User Extensibility‚Äù in the SAP Public Cloud.

 

Purpose of Preparing Customer Aging Analysis Report:

Customer Aging Analysis Report, is a basic financial report which provides the information of outstanding payment from the customer‚Äôs and how long they are due for the payment by categorizing into the Aging Buckets (0 ‚Äì 30 Days, 31 ‚Äì 60 Days, ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶. Above 365 Days).

The aging report provides vital information to management to evaluate how effective the business is at converting sales to cash. The aging report is also used as a tool for estimating potential bad debts, which are then used to revise what is known as the allowance for doubtful accounts.

 

Key-User Extensibility in SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud:

Extensibility covers a broad spectrum of topics that enable customers and partners to adapt standard business software to their business needs.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud key user extensibility allows adapting standard functionalities to user requirements without the need for any external tools. Key User Extensibility is done in the customizing tenant of the development system through SAP Fiori apps designed to facilitate someone making small changes to apps, reports, and email and form templates without any coding experience.

Here's an overview of the things you can do using key user extensibility tools:

  • Change and adapt the UIs for SAP Fiori Apps
  • Create Custom Fields
  • Create your own custom templates or extend the standard forms and email templates
  • Create customer-specific CDS Views
  • Enhance the current business process by creating custom business logic
  • Create a new custom user interface
  • Create custom business objects

SAP S/4HANA embodies key user extensibility tools, which are completely web-based. They are targeted at key users who have a deep knowledge of the product itself, but not necessarily a very deep technical knowledge.

For more details about Extensibility in SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud, please refer the link https://extensibilityexplorer.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/ExtensibilityExplorer/#/ReadMore

To develop the Customized Customer Aging Analysis Report, we are going to use the below Key-User Extensibility Apps and other provided Apps by SAP in the Public Cloud:

  • Custom CDS View APP
  • Custom Analytical Queries APP
  • View Browser APP
  • Custom Catalog Extensions APP

My prior experience in developing Aging Analysis Reports in SAP ECC and S/4HANA GUI with my technical team allowed me to apply the same logic to Custom CDS Views and Custom Analytical Queries, even without knowing any deep technical knowledge.

Let me summarize the business requirement for Customer Aging Analysis before jumping into the technical steps involved for the development:

  • The report should display: Customer Account, Customer Name, Document Number, Line Item, Document Type, GL Account, Payment Terms (with descriptions), and other required fields.
  • The report should calculate and present: Overdue Days, Not Yet Due, Aging Buckets (0-30 days, 31-60 days, ‚Ä¶... and Above 365 days), and Total Overdue Amount.
  • The report balances must be matched with the 'Manage Customer Line Items' App (Accounts Receivable Ledger).

 

In this Part - 1, We will explore how we can utilize the Custom CDS View APP for the AR Aging Analysis Report development.

 

Custom CDS View:

Custom CDS views can serve different purposes: They can be consumed in analytics or serve as external APIs to be consumed in external systems, for instance the SAP BTP. Especially Cube or Dimension views can be used in analytical scenarios and also you can create or modify a custom CDS view by,

  • Adding fields from multiple data sources.
  • Creating your own calculated fields.
  • Refining the properties of the selected fields.
  • Creating and maintaining parameters for the usage within your view.

We have combined the multiple data sources such as I_JournalEntryOperationalView, _I_GLAccountText, and _I_PaymentTermsText to create a Custom CDS View by using the Join Condition.

 

Step ‚Äì 1: Open the APP ‚Äì Custom CDS View

Click on ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù.

 

Enter the ‚ÄúLabel‚Äù, Choose the ‚ÄúScenario‚Äù ‚Äì ‚ÄúAnalytical Cube‚Äù and Click on ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù Button.

Note: By choosing the Scenario as ‚ÄúAnalytical Cube‚Äù, We can use this CDS View to create an Analytical Queries for the Customer Aging Analysis report.

 

Step ‚Äì 2: Choose the Primary Data Source 

Click on ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù Button

Choose the ‚ÄúPrimary Data Source‚Äù

Note: Data Source is an object containing the key figures and characteristics from the database and it provides a multidimensional analytical view of business data.

 

Select the respective ‚ÄúI_JournalEntryOperationalView‚Äù Data Source from the list.

 

This I_JournalEntryOperationalView CDS view provides access to all details of a journal entry item (database table ACDOCA) joined to the details of the corresponding operational accounting document item (database table BSEG) and to the details of the corresponding journal entry header (database table BKPF) including the most important business entity, such as G/L account, Cost Center or Profit Center.

So, this I_JournalEntryOperationalView is similar to the ACDOCA Table which contains the values of all the relevant fields related to the Accounting Document.

 

Step ‚Äì 3: Choose the Associated Data Sources

Click on ‚ÄúAssociated Data Sources‚Äù

Note: Associated Data Sources will help us to combine the two different data sources into one CDS View by using a join condition set between two or more equal characteristics present in the Primary Data Source ‚Äì A and Associated Date Sources ‚Äì B that contains the same data type.

For Example:

The primary data source "I_JournalEntryOperationalView" does not include the "Payment Terms Description" field. Therefore, we must join it with the associated data source "I_PaymentTermsText" using a join condition to retrieve this field.

Select the ‚ÄúJoin Condition‚Äù Icon.

 

Click on ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù

 

Choose the common field that available in the both Primary & Associated Data Source to join.

 

Select the Value Type as ‚ÄúField‚Äù

Click on F4 in the Value Field.

 

Find the corresponding "Payment Terms" mapping field in the Primary Data Source to link it with the field in the Associated Data Source.

 

Select the Value Type as ‚ÄúSession Variable‚Äù

Choose the Value as ‚ÄúSystem Language‚Äù and Click on ‚ÄúClose‚Äù button.

 

Step ‚Äì 4: Choose the Elements (Fields) to be added in the CDS View

In the Elements Section, Click on ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù button and Choose ‚ÄúElements‚Äù.

In the Elements selection pop up screen,

Choose the ‚ÄúElements (Fields)‚Äù from ‚ÄúI_JournalEntryOperationalView‚Äù you want to display in the CDS view and then Click on ‚ÄúOK‚Äù.

Total 142 Elements (Fields) have been selected for the CDS view.

 

Step ‚Äì 5: Create User Defined Parameters

User-Defined Parameters:

Parameters usually require data input when your custom CDS view is executed. This data can then be used like a variable e.g. in filters, calculated fields or even in a join condition to another view. You can then refine them or just create your own parameters if you need them.

The Customer Aging Analysis Report will operate based on "Open Items at Key Date," mirroring the functionality found in reports like "Manage Customer Line Item" or "FBL5N."

The "Open Items at Key Date" logic ensures that when the report is run for a specific date (which can be in the past, present, or future), it will only display items that meet following criteria mentioned below:

  • The open items (Invoices, Payments, & Advances) were not yet cleared as of the specified key date will be included in the report.
  • The open items (Invoices, Payments, & Advances) were cleared after the specified key date will be included in the report.
  • The open items (Invoices, Payments, & Advances) were cleared before the specified key date will be excluded from the report.

This "Key Date" will serve as a crucial input on the report's selection screen, driving the logic for determining which open items are included in the Customer Aging Report.

In the Parameters Section, Click on ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù button,

Enter the following information:

  • Name: Technical Name
  • Label: Name to be displayed in the output of the parameter
  • Data Type: ‚ÄúDATS‚Äù ‚Äì Date (YYYYMMDD Format) Data type of the parameter.
  • Default Type and Value: ‚ÄúManual‚Äù - Enter a manual parameter value in accordance with the data type syntax, e.g. for the data type DATS enter a manual value in the format YYYYMMDD.

Now the ‚ÄúOpen Items at Key Date‚Äù Parameter is created. 

 

Step ‚Äì 6: Add User Defined Parameters in the Elements (Fields)

In the Elements Section, Click on ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù Button and Choose the ‚ÄúParameters‚Äù.

Select the created ‚ÄúOpen Items at Key Date‚Äù Parameter and Click on ‚ÄúOK‚Äù button.

Now the ‚ÄúOpen Items at Key Date‚Äù Parameter has been added in the Elements.

 

Step ‚Äì 7: Using ‚ÄúFilter‚Äù Applying the Logic for the Customer Aging Analysis Report

You can filter the information shown in your custom CDS view by setting up a condition, just like using the WHERE clause in SQL. This condition provides the view exactly what data to show.

Think of it like this:

The CDS view (I_JournalEntryOperationalView) which we are using that shows all the Accounting Document transactions in line item wise.

  • If you want to display only Customer related Accounting Transactions, you'd set a condition like "Account Type is equal to ‚ÄúD".
  • Or, if you only want to see Normal Transactions (Invoices, Payments) & Special GL Transactions (Advances), your condition would be "Special GL Code equal to ‚ÄúBLANK‚Äù, & ‚ÄúA‚Äù.

Once you set this condition (using either a simple editor or a form-based one), your CDS view will automatically filter its results, showing only the open items that match what you asked for. It's a way to fine-tune the data you see without having to look through everything.

We can use the form-based version to define simple filter conditions. In case you want to define more complex conditions, we can use expression-based version. Here, we have used expression-based version.

As per business requirement, to ensure the Customer Aging Analysis Report balances match with the "Manage Customer Line Items" balances, we've set up specific conditions for these fields: Account Type, Special GL Code, Posting Date, and Clearing Date in the Filter section using expression-based version.

 

Step ‚Äì 8: Create Calculation Elements (Fields) ‚Äì Overdue Days & Payment Terms Days

In the Elements section, click on ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù button and Choose ‚ÄúCalculation‚Äù to create Overdue Days & Payment Terms Days fields for the report.

  1. Overdue Days

Enter the following information:

  • Name: Technical Name
  • Label: Name to be displayed in the output of the parameter
  • Choose as ‚ÄúFunction‚Äù and Choose ‚ÄúFunction Type ‚Äì Date and Time‚Äù
  • Choose the respective ‚ÄúFunction - DATS_DAYS_BETWEEN‚Äù and apply the below mentioned formula.
  • Then click on ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù.

Note: The function DATS_DAYS_BETWEEN calculates the difference between two specified dates, date1 and date2, in days. The actual parameters must have the predefined data type DATS and should contain a valid date in the format YYYYMMDD.

The Formula we have applied to calculate the Overdue Days is Open Items Key Date (which was created as parameter for report execution) MINUS Net Due Date. 

 

  1. Payment Terms Days

Enter the following information:

  • Name: Technical Name
  • Label: Name to be displayed in the output of the parameter
  • Choose as ‚ÄúFunction‚Äù and Choose ‚ÄúFunction Type ‚Äì Date and Time‚Äù
  • Choose the respective ‚ÄúFunction - DATS_DAYS_BETWEEN‚Äù and apply the below mentioned formula.
  • Then click on ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù.

The Formula we have applied to calculate the Payment Terms Days is Net Due Date MINUS Baseline Date.

Created Calculation Elements (Fields) for the report.

In the Element Properties Section, Maintain the Aggregation method as ‚ÄúNo Operation‚Äù for the created Payment Term Days & Overdue Days Fields to convert the field into calculated measure for creating the Aging Buckets in the Custom Analytical Query APP.

 

Step ‚Äì 9: Preview and Publish the created CDS view

In the Log section, check any error need to rectified before preview the CDS view.

Click on ‚ÄúPreview Data‚Äù button to display the values are coming as per the logic or not.

 

Created CDS View no of line items are matching with the Manage Customer Line Items.

Calculated Fields (Overdue Days, Payment Terms Days) are displaying with values in the CDS View according formula we have applied in the calculation function.

Once Check is successful, Go to ‚ÄúNext Steps‚Äù section.

Click on ‚ÄúPublish‚Äù button to publish the Created CDS View for Creating Analytical Queries.

In Part - 2, we'll dive into using the Custom Analytical Queries APP with our newly created Custom CDS View to build an AR Aging Analysis Report.

entry.title: Frequent used CDS Views in Cloud ERP, Public Edition
entry.content:
In this blog, we will introduce several frequent used CDS view with use cases that raised to me in Cloud ERP, Public Edition. Your feedback is invaluable to us. Please kudos this post so we can gauge its usefulness and prioritize further expansion of the content.

Should you have additional use-cases or requirements, share them in the comments‚Äîtogether we‚Äôll enrich this resource into a comprehensive reference. This blog heavily rely on APP Customer Data Browser,  Fiori ID F5746 with different scenarios.

The features covered in this article are based on SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition 2508, please refer to the latest information for changes in subsequent versions.

Index

I_GoodsMovementCube

I_PURCHASEORDERITEMAPI01

i_materialdocumentitem_2

I_JournalEntry

I_SALESORDER

I_SuplrInvcItemPurOrdRefAPI01

I_EnterpriseProjectElement

 

I_GoodsMovementCube

Use case: Is there any standard app that can directly export the relevant purchase orders based on ‚ÄúPurchasing Group + actual posting date‚Äù? For example, a list of all purchase orders already posted by a certain buyer between 1 Jan 2025 and 30 Jun 2025.

Solution:

This CDS view is corresponding to APP Goods Movement Analysis with most fields to select from.

First of all there is unfortunately no standard app to achieve the goal so we have a workaround and basically you can follow this procedure to achieve your customized reporting requirement.

Step 1:  APP Customer Data Browser

Click the CDS View tab and key in I_GoodsMovementCube in the search box.

Step 2:  Customize the filter

Extend the filter field according to your need. Here we select two fields: Posting Date in the document and purchasing group

Step 3: Customize the reporting result

Select additional two fields in the setting on the result. You have 102 fields to select from.

Here is the final result you may want:

 

I_PURCHASEORDERITEMAPI01

This CDS View corresponds to APP Monitor purchase Order item

 

i_materialdocumentitem_2

This CDS View has smaller set of field comparing to I_GoodsMovementCube. Eg no purchasing group field so this CDS view is not picked.

 

I_JournalEntry

 

I_SALESORDER

 

I_SuplrInvcItemPurOrdRefAPI01

Use case: User would like to add a duplication check when 'Park' or 'hold' an supplier invoice in APP 'Park Supplier Invoice'. If the purchase order item has exiting invoice with status 'Posted', then stop Park or hold again with error message pop up.

Solution: since I_SuplrInvcItemPurOrdRefAPI01 is not released and could not be view in APP Customer Data Browser, we need to create a customize CDS view.

Step 1: Create a customize CDS view via APP Custom CDS Views (F1866A) and publish

Step 2: Find which field representing the posting status :

Go to APP Customer data Browser and test to confirm which field and what value means park

According to my test, the field SupplierInvoiceStatus with the following value can tell the difference

'A' = 'Parked'

'B' = 'Completed'

'C' = 'Hold'

'5' = 'Posted'

Step 3: Add customer logic leveraging the above customized CDS

You can refer to Âú® SAP S/4HANA Cloud ‰∏≠ÈÄöËøáËá™ÂÆö‰πâÈÄªËæëÈôêÂà∂Êú™ÂÆåÊàêÊî∂Ë¥ßÁöÑÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢ÂçïÂºÄÁ•® - SAP Community for detailed abap coding.
