entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP Fiori Launchpad
entry.content:
This second post in my series gives an overview of user experience innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and the SAP Fiori launchpad which are now generally available. It covers Joule and many AI-assisted UX innovations, new collaboration capabilities as well as improvements in details. The next post will cover additional innovations available to customers for beta testing.

Users in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition can query SAP Analytics Cloud directly via Joule. Read about this and more in the first blog post introducing the series and providing general information about Joule and central entry points and services:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

This post gives an overview of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition UX innovations in these areas:

  • SAP Fiori launchpad and Design Updates for Suite Consistency
  • My Home
  • AI-Assisted UX Features
  • Collaboration: Integration of To Dos for Situations in Microsoft Teams
  • UX Improvements in Details

Many of the UX improvements in details are enabled by our UI framework (SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements) and hence also available to customers and partners developing their own applications. Note however that the enabled AI-assisted features are only available for extensions built directly on the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system.

Below you‚Äôll see those AI innovations with largest impact on user experience, but you can get a more comprehensive overview of the latest AI innovations in these blog posts:

  • Highlights of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release.
  • Exploring AI and next-gen Cloud ERP innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.
  • Try the latest AI features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 (covering the AI-assisted features enabled by our UI framework).

 

SAP Fiori Launchpad and Design Updates for Suite Consistency

We have made design improvements which are relevant for a consistent user experience across the entire SAP Business Suite, and which are now available with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508. As I mentioned in my April blog post Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web), consistency of the user experience across the various applications used by a user is an important part of overall usability, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products ‚Äì no unexpected surprises.

In this section, we‚Äôll look at four design updates provided by the SAP Fiori launchpad, as well as examples of the new design for illustrations, and some updates for launchpad administrators:

  • Navigation menu: Side navigation
  • Updated shell bar
  • Updated user menu
  • Updated notifications
  • New illustrations design
  • Update for administrators

Navigation Menu: Side Navigation

Many SAP products already offer a navigation menu on the left of the screen, a pattern already familiar to many people. Hence we have decided to apply that approach to navigation across the SAP Business Suite in upcoming releases.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the side navigation is displayed as an overlay, as you can see in Figure 1. It gives you direct access to your favorite apps, either directly or via the folders you have created. It also gives you direct access to your Spaces and Pages. The previously available menu to access all your spaces and pages along with personalization options is available via the entry ‚ÄúAll Spaces‚Äù at the bottom of the menu.

A big benefit of this new navigation menu is that you can now access your favorite apps directly from any application. Previously, you would have to return to My Home and then click on your favorite app, now you can access it directly from the menu, as shown in Figure 1.

Figure 1: The new navigation menu, opened up from the new shell bar, showing direct access to Favourite Apps, My Spaces and All Spaces. Alt Text: an image showing a list of sales orders and on the left a pop-over with a navigation menu with the sections already mentioned. Below the ‚ÄúFavourite App‚Äù eight apps are listed as well as two folders for favorite apps, plus the folder ‚ÄúInsights‚Äù for the insight tiles.

New Shell Bar ‚Äì need to switch it on!

The new shell bar design for the SAP Business Suite is available for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The immediately visible difference is that now the product name is displayed to the right of the SAP Logo, in this case ‚ÄúS/4HANA Cloud‚Äù as you can see at the top of Figure 1. The logo and the name are all contained within a clickable area, which brings the user to the start page (i.e. My Home).

The new shell bar enables the next two design updates to the user menu and to notifications.

By default, after upgrading, the old shell bar will be shown, with the new navigation menu. We advise that you check any test automation and RPA (Robotic Process Automation) you may have before switching on the new shell bar, since you may need to make some adjustments ‚Äì in particular if you log off at the end of a test.

You can switch on the new shell bar via the Activate New Features application, with the feature ‚Äú/UI2/SHELL_BAR_TOGGLE‚Äù, which is planned to become available mid-August 2025.

Updated User Menu

The new user menu design shown in Figure 2 provides more space for the avatar of the user, and provides more space between items for easier selection. The settings are always at the top as the first entry, and the ‚ÄúSign Out‚Äù option is separated from the actual navigation options in the list, to make it easier to find.

Figure 2: Updated design of user menu and notifications. Alt Text: On the left an image of the previous user menu and the updated user menu. On the right an image of the updated notifications list, showing four notifications in the group ‚ÄúLast Month‚Äù, each with a title, two lines of description and a line with the data and a ‚Äúmore‚Äù link.

Updated Notifications Design

The new simplified design of notifications shown on the right in Figure 2  fits better with the overall design of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and provides simplier interactions. By default notifications are sorted by date, with grouping by ‚ÄúToday‚Äù, ‚ÄúYesterday‚Äù, ‚ÄúLast Week‚Äù, ‚ÄúLast Month‚Äù. Users can also choose to sort by importance.

New Illustrations Design

We have modernized the design of our illustrations, and also made them easier to understand. Figure 3 shows two examples ‚Äì one for indicating that something went wrong (the fallen ice cream cone), one for search, with an example of where the search illustration is used when opening a list report application without any filter values defined.

Figure 3: Examples of new illustrations. Alt Text: On the left top three different size illustrations showing an ice cream cone fallen on the ground; bottom left an illustration of a globe with a magnifying glass, representing ‚Äúsearch‚Äù. On the right an image of a list report showing the search illustration since no data has been selected.

Update for Administrators of SAP Fiori Launchpad

Hiding of Empty Spaces and Pages

Empty Spaces and Pages are now automatically hidden from users. Until now this was an option which administrators needed to switch on, now it is on by default.

You might be asking how a space or page could be empty? The apps which a user sees on a page on the SAP Fiori launchpad, and the pages which appear in a space, depend on a user‚Äôs authorizations. This can lead to a page being defined in such a way that certain users are not authorized to use any of the apps therein; similarly, a space can end up not having any pages available to a user. Now, if this happens, any such empty pages or spaces are hidden from the user, rather than being shown empty.

Redesign of Apps for Managing Spaces and Pages

Up until now, the apps ‚ÄúManage Launchpad Spaces‚Äù and ‚ÄúManage Launchpad Pages‚Äù distinguished between entries which could be edited within a given tenant and entries which could only be used as templates when creating new spaces or pages. The editable ones were listed in the tab ‚ÄúCustomer-Created‚Äù, the others in the tab ‚ÄúPredefined‚Äù.

Our customers gave us feedback that this was in fact confusing, because a page which was listed as ‚ÄúCustomer-Created‚Äù in a non-productive tenant and which was transferred to a productive tenant became ‚ÄúPredefined‚Äù there, i.e. it was not listed under ‚ÄúCustomer-Created‚Äù despite it being customer-created.

Now, the design has been changed, with two tabs for editable entities (spaces or pages) and non-editable ones. For example, in the app ‚ÄúManage Launchpad Pages‚Äù, the tabs are called ‚ÄúPages‚Äù and ‚ÄúPage Templates‚Äù, as shown in Figure 4. No matter what tenant you are in, you cannot change or edit page templates, you can only use them to create new pages. The same applies to spaces in the Manage Launchpad Spaces app.

Figure 4: The redesigned app Manage Launchpad Pages with Tabs for ‚ÄúPages‚Äù and ‚ÄúPage Templates‚Äù. Alt Text: image shows an extract of the app showing the two tabs.

For more information about the visual updates, and what‚Äôs new, check out:

  • Blog post: Transforming User Experience: SAP Fiori Launchpad adopts the latest SAP Design System updates.
  • What‚Äôs New: SAP Fiori launchpad in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.

 

My Home

My Home is proving very popular with users, and we hope to make it even more so with the innovations in the 2508 release:

  • The salutation bar, welcoming users and providing interesting options.
  • Recap ‚Äì summarizing what changed since you last logged on.
  • Manage News application for customer-specific news.
  • AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for insights cards
    (this is covered in the next section AI-Assisted UX Innovations)

We are also providing two new features for beta-testing, AI-assisted smart personalization for applications and AI-assisted smart solution for situations in My Home, which I will showcase in part 3 in this series of blog posts.

Salutation Bar in My Home

The new salutation bar shown in Figure 5 welcomes users to the system, and gives them direct access to My Home settings as well as to the new Recap feature explained below. Optionally, you can set the system up to let business users see what‚Äôs next on their calendar. (Not shown in Figure 5. Use communication arrangement SAP_COM_0887 to set enable it).

Figure 5: The new salutation bar in My Home, showing the welcome text ‚ÄúHi Barbara, Great to see you again!‚Äù and the beta AI option ‚ÄúAdd Content‚Äù, plus the options ‚ÄúRecap‚Äù and ‚ÄúMy Home Settings‚Äù. Alt Text: Image shows My Home with a new dark. Blue bar just below the header, with today‚Äôs date top left, below which in larger font ‚ÄúHi Barbara, Great to see you again!‚Äù is written. On the right of the bar three buttons are shown: the AI button ‚ÄúAdd Content‚Äù, ‚ÄúRecap‚Äù, and ‚ÄúMy Home Settings‚Äù.

Recap

With the new recap feature, you can get a quick overview of what has changed on My Home in the last 24 or more hours: new or processed tasks, situations, apps and insight cards. It compares your current My Home data against a snapshot of data captured from your last login that was over 24 hours ago. It shows you what has changed or been added within that timeframe. This saves you a lot of time, since you don‚Äôt have to scan everything manually, and ensures that you are all caught up quickly ‚Äì and don‚Äôt miss any important changes. What is great about it is that it is visual, showing before and after images of insight cards ‚Äì you can see an example in Figure 6, or watch it in action in this video:

  • Video: Recap Feature of My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (0:55 min.)

Figure 6: Recap in My Home, showing a change in an insight card, where one additional quotation has expired, and one additional quotation will expire after a week. Alt Text: a popover on top of My Home, with a ‚ÄúSummary‚Äù section on the left containing three items ‚ÄúTasks‚Äù, ‚ÄúSituations‚Äù, and ‚ÄúCards‚Äù, with ‚ÄúCards‚Äù selected. The right shows two tabs, ‚ÄúChanged (3)‚Äù (selected) and ‚ÄúRemoved (2)‚Äù, below which a card marked ‚Äúold‚Äù with a horizontal bar chart is shown on the left, and the same card with updated data marked ‚Äúnew‚Äù on the right.

Manage News Application

I‚Äôm glad to announce that administrators can now easily create their own news to be displayed on My Home, using the new Manage News application. Figure 7 shows the start page of the application, listing news articles.

You can specify title, subtitle and main text, a background image, the start and end dates, as well as categorizing and targeting the news for specific groups of users or roles.

Figure 7: Manage News application. Alt Text: Screenshot of the Manage News application, showing a filter bar and a list of two news articles with their title, subtitle, footer text, criticality, status ‚Äúpublished‚Äù and publish start and end dates.

To get a better impression of how it works, watch this video:

  • Video: Manage News Application in My Home for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (2:00 min.)

You can find out more about these My Home innovations here:

  • My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 - What's new?.
  • Empowering Business Users with Personalized News in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Release.
  • My Home documentation.

 

AI-Assisted User Experience

When AI is embedded directly into the application UI to give users a better user experience, as opposed to being accessed via the Joule window, we talk about ‚ÄúAI-Assisted User Experience‚Äù.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, we distinguish between AI base features and premium features:

  • Base features are free of charge, and only require that the customer signs the SAP AI Terms, which can be done via this link.
  • Premium features require SAP AI Units to be in place. Those listed here also require Joule Premium for Financial Management. Customers can activate this via SAP for Me -> Portfolio & Products -> Business AI.

The following are now generally available as base features:

  • AI-assisted enterprise search (which was in beta testing with the 2502 release). See below for more details.
  • AI-assisted easy filter.
  • AI-assisted smart summarization.

The latter two were generally available under limited promotion with the 2502 release, now they are generally available out of the box ‚Äì no need to sign up to the limited promotion. To find out more about them, look at these blog posts:

  • SAP UX Q1/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502 and SAP Fiori Launchpad
  • AI-assisted easy filter enhancements with 2508: Try the latest AI features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.

The following premium feature is now generally available:

  • AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for insight cards.
    See below for more details.

AI-Assisted Enterprise Search

You can now use natural language in the search field available at the top of every screen in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, making it even easier to benefit from powerful enterprise search capabilities. With enterprise search, you can find the information you need directly, without having to specify the name of the application ‚Äì as you can see in Figure 8. This is available out of the box as a base feature.

Figure 8: AI-assisted enterprise search, showing how you can easily find business data directly using natural language. Alt Text: A short video showing how a user can enter in the search field in the shell header bar ‚ÄúShow me all sales orders with net value greater than 5000 eur‚Äù and get a corresponding list sales orders. The user than adds the text ‚Äúthat are in process‚Äù resulting in a list with fewer results.

Watch the full video:

  • Video:  AI-Assisted Enterprise Search in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition  (0:48 min.)

AI-Assisted Smart Personalization of My Home for Insight Cards

With this premium feature, you can now use natural language to add an insight card to My Home. You just have to describe what information you want to see on the card, and the system will create the card for you. We ensure that the user is in control by first showing a preview of the card, allowing the user to either confirm, or rephrase the request. Figure 9 shows the kind of text you can use, and figure 10 gives you an idea of the interaction flow.

Note that this functionality is currently only supported by 20 applications, which are listed in this blog post.

Figure 9: AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for insight cards, showing an example prompt and the resulting card. Alt Text: a popover ‚ÄúAdd Insights Cards‚Äù above My Home is shown, with a text entry field on the left containing the AI prompt ‚Äúcreate a card showing sales orders in overall status open and delivery block status blocked with fields sold-to-party, requested delivery date and net value‚Äù, below that an AI ‚ÄúGenerate‚Äù and a ‚ÄúClear all‚Äù button, below that some sample queries, on the right the card preview showing ‚ÄúOpen Sales Orders‚Äù with sub-title ‚ÄúWith Delivery Block‚Äù.

 

Figure 10: AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for insight cards in action. Alt Text: a short video showing the prompt from Figure 9 being entered, and the card being generated and added to the Insights section of My Home.

Watch the full video:

  • Video:  AI-Assisted Smart Personalization of My Home for Insights Cards in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition  (0:54 min.)

AI-Assisted Financial Business Insights

Users in Finance now benefit from AI-generated analysis and summaries built into the following review booklets:

  • Cost Centers Review Booklet
  • Group Finanical Statements Review Booklet
  • Project Financial Booklet ‚Äì Professional Services

Watch this video to get an overview for the cost centers review booklet:

  • Video: AI-Assisted Financial Business Insights (1:20 minutes)

Simplified Asset Accounting with SAP Business AI

With Joule and AI embedded in the applications, asset accountants can get their work done more easily now, with:

  • AI-assisted asset creation with Joule.
  • Easy to understand AI-generated natural language explanations of depreciation keys.
  • AI-generated value calculation insights.

Figure 11: AI-generated asset valuation explanation, after the user clicked on the AI-button ‚ÄúExplain Key Figures‚Äù. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a table summarizing the asset valuation, with an AI button ‚ÄúExplain Key Figures‚Äù in the table heading. Below the table a section ‚ÄúExplain Key Figures‚Äù is shown, with a text explaining how the depreciation is calculated.

Have a look at this video to see all three of these in action:

  • Video: Simplify Asset Accounting with SAP Business AI and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (3:25 minutes).

 

Collaboration: Integration of To Dos for Situations in Microsoft Teams

In addition to being able to process To Dos for tasks directly in Microsoft Teams (as I featured in my February blog post), you can now also process To Dos for Business Situations directly in Microsoft Teams.

This means that you get notified in your Teams activity feed about new Business Situations, and you can process Business Situations in place, without having to leave Teams, as you can see in Figure 12.

Figure 12: To Dos for Business Situations are available via Activities in Microsoft Teams. Alt Text: Two screenshots are shown, the top one shows an row of Situation cards in My Home, the bottom one shows the Activity view in Teams, with the activity ‚ÄúSituations in SAP S/4HANA‚Äù and sub-text ‚ÄúThere are 9 situations for you‚Äù selected on the left, and the right two thirds of the screen showing a list with the same situations as shown in My Home.

To enable this, you need to install the SAP S/4HANA for Microsoft Teams app.

For further information:

  • Video: To Dos in Microsoft Teams (1:00)
  • Documentation: Integrating Microsoft Teams.

 

UX Improvements in Details

The details matter for a great user experience, so we continue to gather user feedback and work on improving these details, which though relatively small can have a big impact on user satisfaction. Let‚Äôs have a look at the highlights of what we are improving with the 2508 release.

Improved performance for scrolling in grid tables

Our engineers have done some magic so that now scrolling is very fast in grid tables, which are the table type typically used for working with large volumes of data.

Why do I call it magic? Well, modern web-based UIs have the UI layer running in the browser, managing direct user interactions, and calling services in the backend to get and update data. However, if you are working with a list of say over 100,000 items, you would have to wait quite a long time when starting the application until all items have been loaded into the browser. Hence we only load a certain number to start with, such as 100. This however means that when a user scrolls beyond the 100 which have been loaded, additional data needs to be fetched from the backend, which slows down scrolling. Now, our engineers have found a way to minimize this effect to almost zero, so that you have fast scrolling all the time ‚Äì magic!

Figure 13: Performance improvement for scrolling in grid tables. Alt Text: a short video showing scrolling through a grid table.

Whenever the threshold is reached and more data needs to be loaded, there is a very short delay, with the progress indicator being shown for a few milliseconds, as you can see in Figure 13. In most cases, this is completely negligible. Nevertheless, we do also provide customers the option to change the number of entries loaded by default when the application is started. This is useful if a customer knows that, for a certain application, the number of entries will not exceed 2.000 for example. Then they can set the threshold to 2.000, which means that the application will take a little bit longer to load first time around, but then scrolling will be instantaneous for all the data. Figure 14 shows the UI for doing this, as part of UI adaptation. The ‚ÄúThreshold‚Äù determines the maximum number of entries loaded when the application is started, the ‚ÄúScroll Threshold‚Äù determines the maximum number that are loaded during scrolling if new entries need to be fetched.

Figure 14: UI adaptation to determine the threshold determining the maximum number of entries loaded in a table when an application is started. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over ‚ÄúConfigure Table‚Äù with two new fields ‚ÄúThreshold‚Äù, being edited with the value 3000, and ‚ÄúScroll Threshold‚Äù, containing the value 300.

Sort or Group Tables by ID or Description

SAP Fiori apps display the ID and the description in the same column within a table, which provides a better experience than having them in two separate columns.

Now, we offer users a choice when sorting or grouping the table by a column which contains both ID and description: they can choose to do this by ID or by description. As you can see in Figure 15, this selection is very intuitive. The example shows what it looks like when sorting by Company Code. At the bottom of the table you see an entry ‚Äú1710 (BestRun US)‚Äù, where the Company Code (the ID) is 1710 and the Company Name (the Description) is ‚ÄúBestRun US‚Äù. In the popover ‚ÄúSort By‚Äù section, the row of icons next to Company Code and Company Name indicate that currently no sorting is active, with the option to sort either bei Code or by Name ascending or descending.

Figure 15: Sort or group tables by ID (in this case Company Code) or by Description (Company Name) when both are displayed together in one column . Alt Text: A screenshot of part of the Manage Journal Entries app, with a list of journal entries and a pop-over ‚ÄúColumn Settings‚Äù with two sections ‚ÄúSort By‚Äù and ‚ÄúGroup By‚Äù. The ‚ÄúSort By‚Äù section has two lines, ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù and ‚ÄúCompany Name‚Äù, and offers three buttons with icons for each of these, representing ‚Äúno sorting‚Äù, ‚Äúascending‚Äù, ‚Äúdescending‚Äù.

Hiding Description Fields in List of Fields in Table Settings

For tables as above where ID and description are displayed in one column, technically, the ID and description are stored in two different fields. Until now, when users personalize the table, both the ID and the description were listed in the list of columns, which confused some users.

Now, we have addressed this by providing the option to hide the descriptions (see Figure 16), and hence simplifying personalization. This option is on by default, i.e. the description fields are automatically hidden now.

Figure 16: Description fields can be hidden from the list of fields shown when personalizing tables. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over ‚ÄúView Settings‚Äù containing tabs ‚ÄúColumns‚Äù, ‚ÄúSort‚Äù, ‚ÄúFilter‚Äù, and a pop-over ‚ÄúFilters‚Äù with two options ‚ÄúHide descriptions‚Äù (selected) and ‚ÄúHide Unselected‚Äù (deselected) . ‚ÄúColumns‚Äù is selected and shows a list of columns with check marks. The third entry is ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù, followed by ‚ÄúCreated On‚Äù ‚Äì i.e. the description column ‚ÄúCompany Name‚Äù is not listed next to the ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù.

Key Users Can Rearrange ID and Description Within a Field or Column

SAP applications come with a standard arrangement of ID and description within a field or a column, based on user research. We have found that for financial users, it is usually best to have the ID first and the description in brackets: Company Code (Company Description), for example ‚Äú1710 (BestRun US)‚Äù as shown in Figure 15. For users in sales and logistics, it is usually best to have the name first and the ID in brackets: for example Customer Name (Customer ID), for example ‚ÄúUS Specialty Cycles 5 (USCU_S05)‚Äù as shown in Figure 1.

Now, key users can use UI adaptation to rearrange the order for a given application. Doing this change applies then to all occurrences of the field in the application, i.e. the filter bar, the table or in a form on an object page.

Table Grouping and/or ‚ÄúShow more per row‚Äù State can be Shared

If a user personalizes a table by grouping entries by one of the fields, such as the date, this grouping is persisted when sharing the link with a colleague: when the colleague opens the application with the link, they see the same grouping applied.

Similarly, if ‚Äúshow more per row‚Äù was selected by the user before sharing the link, the recipient will also see more information per row upon opening the application via the link. This information is also stored when saving a view of a table.

Documentation of Keyboard Shortcuts within Applications

Power users are often quicker when only using the keyboard, rather than switching back and forth between keyboard and mouse ‚Äì but only if they know all the relevant keyboard shortcuts. With the 2508 release we provide information about available keyboard shortcuts directly where you need them, in the context of the application. By selecting ‚ÄúKeyboard Shortcuts‚Äù in the user menu, a new window appears explaining all the available shortcuts for the application area currently in focus. If you click on a different part of the application, or navigate somewhere else, then the window showing the available shortcuts is updated immediately for the new context.

Figure 17 shows an example for Manage Journal Entries, where the focus is currently on the filter bar. Clicking on the the table results in many more shortcuts being shown, for example for the arrow keys for moving up and down etc., as shown in Figure 18.

Figure 17: In-context documentation of keyboard shortcuts, for the filter bar. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app ‚ÄúManage Journal Entries‚Äù with the focus on the filter bar, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, ‚ÄúGlobal Shortcuts‚Äù and ‚ÄúGeneric Keyboard Interactions‚Äù.

Figure 18: In-context documentation of keyboard shortcuts, for the table. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app ‚ÄúManage Journal Entries‚Äù with the focus on the table, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, ‚ÄúGlobal Shortcuts‚Äù and ‚ÄúJournal Entries (43,854)‚Äù. The latter contains descriptions for shortcuts for the table, such as the arrow up, down, left, right keys, or using ‚ÄúCmd + D‚Äù to delete.

These are the highlights of our changes in details. For the full list, have a look at the What‚Äôs New Viewer:

  • UX in What‚Äôs New Viewer for  SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.

 

Continue Reading with an overview of new UX Innovations for Beta Testing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508

I hope you enjoyed this second part, covering what is now generally available with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP Fiori launchpad. Here is a link to part three, covering exciting new UX innovations available for beta testing with the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 3: Beta AI Innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.

Do keep posting your experiences and recommendations yourself in the SAP Community, with the SAP Fiori and/or the User Experience tag! In case you are wondering how to get a list of the most recent blog posts on SAP Fiori and User Experience in our new SAP Community, use these links:

  • Latest blog posts on SAP Fiori in the SAP Community.
  • Latest blog posts on User Experience in the SAP Community.

entry.title: Extend a Custom Business Object created with Key User Extensibility using SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
This blog post covers how to setup an extension scenario from SAP S/4HANA Cloud and build Side-by-Side UI Extensions with the help of SAP Build Apps in the Business Technology Platform.

Business scenario:

A Manager wants to define business objects ‚ÄúBonus Plan‚Äù for employees. A Bonus Plan is there to save employee specific rules for bonus entitlement.

Here, with Key User Extensibility, we create a custom Business Object with a data structure, logic for data initialization in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition which should have standard API operations (GET, POST, DELETE). Expose the custom business object as web service for side-by-side UI extension using Low-code No-code capabilities of SAP Build Apps. You will learn how quickly a new UI application can be developed with the no-code capabilities of SAP Build Apps. You will also find out what is the process to setup, develop and deploy a productive extension application.

Note: The maintain Bonus app shown in this blog is for educational purpose only and not meant for productive usage. It is not ensured that the data used in this extension scenario is managed in accordance with applicable legal requirements for all countries and industries and in accordance with the business needs, such as data life cycle requirements.  

Prerequisites:

  1. Subscription to SAP Build Apps on SAP BTP Sub-Account
  2. Your user needs (a) business role(s) with business catalogs Extensibility - Custom Business Objects (ID: SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_CBO), Extensibility - Custom Communication Scenarios (ID: SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_CCS) and Communication Management (ID: SAP_CORE_BC_COM) (Need to have unrestricted access if you are creating a business role and adding these catalogs).
  3. You have Created Custom Business Objects in SAP S/4HANA Cloud as per the given tutorial.                                                                

Why SAP Build Apps with SAP S/4HANA Cloud?

Create new solutions using the secure, no-code SAP Build Apps with SAP S/4HANA. Build visually and empower users to digitalise their daily work without impacting core processes. Create a personalised, accessible application that securely connects to data from SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

To extend SAP S/4HANA Cloud using SAP Build Apps, you can leverage side-by-side extensibility, which allows you to build extensions that run on SAP BTP and interact with your S/4HANA Cloud system. This approach enables you to create custom UIs, logic, and integrations without directly modifying the core S/4HANA Cloud system. 

 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Let‚Äôs start on the SAP S/4HANA Cloud side with the definition of the Custom Business Object and the communication settings.

Custom Business Object

In the Create Custom Business Objects in SAP S/4HANA Cloud tutorial group it is shown how to create a custom business object and generate a UI (user interface) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Expose Custom Business Object as External API

To integrate custom business object from SAP S/4HANA system with External Systems or Services like SAP Build Apps, as administrator you need to create a Communication Arrangement. You create a communication arrangement to enable the communication between your system and SAP Build App in BTP, and how they communicate. Communication Arrangement is formed by combining the below artifacts:

  1. Creating a Custom Communication Scenario
    The setup of the communication (inbound and outbound) between SAP S/4HANA and SAP BTP starts with the definition of a Custom Communication Scenario.
    The Custom Communication Scenario contains the information for both inbound and outbound HTTP-calls.
    • Open the app Custom Communication Scenarios in the Launchpad of the SAP S/4 HANA system and create a new Custom Communication Scenario with the name YY1_BONUSPLAN.

     

    • On the tab Inbound Services, you create an entry for your Custom Business Object: Press Add button to add inbound service ‚ÄúYY1_BONUSPLAN_CDS‚Äù and click select button. 

     

    • Press Save and Publish to finish the custom communication scenario creation.

     

  2. Creating a Communication System and User

    To enable secure communication between different systems you have to register these systems and define the user which is authorized to use the connection.

    The communication system represents the communication partner within a communication. for inbound communication, this is the external system that calls our custom Bonus plan service.

    We‚Äôll create one Communication System for all systems that want to use our service as well as the user that they‚Äôll have to use. If you want to access the custom BONUSPLAN OData service (Inbound) you also need to setup an authentication method. You can use several methods like e.g.., Basic Authentication, Certificate or OAuth.

    In this case we are choosing Basic Authentication for which you need to setup a Communication User. Open the app Maintain Communication Users from the Communication Management group and create there a new user with username, description, and password.

    • Open ‚ÄúCommunication Systems‚Äù Application.
    • Start creating a new system by executing the ‚ÄúNew‚Äù action.
    • Give following data to the new custom communication System‚Ä¶

    Note: you can replace XXX with your system ID.

    Field Label

    Field Value

    System ID

    EXTERNAL_SYSTEMXXX

    System Name

    EXTERNAL_SYSTEMXXX

    Host Name

    EXTERNAL_SYSTEMXXX

    • Scroll down to ‚ÄúUser for Inbound Communication‚Äù and start adding one by executing the ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù action.
    • In the Pop Up, use the value help to browse and select the user.

     

    • Choose the user you already created and then click OK. Your user for Inbound Communication is set up. Click on Save.

  3. Creating a Communication Arrangement for Custom Communication Scenario

Finally, a communication arrangement links the solution‚Äôs scenario with the Communication system and its user and exposes the Service to be used.

  • Open ‚ÄúCommunication Arrangements‚Äù Application
  • Start creation by executing the ‚ÄúNew‚Äù action.
  • A pop up opens in that you use the value help for Scenario first where you can select previously created Custom Communication Scenario YY1_BONUSPLAN. This will set the Scenario and default the Arrangement Name, so that you can continue the creation via ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù button.

  • In the opening Arrangement details click to browse the Communication System
  • Choose the EXTERNAL_SYSTEMXXX you created before.
  • Choosing the system will automatically set the related User as well. Click Save to finish creation
  • Copy the Service URL for the next step. Here you save the inbound service URL for the destination configuration in BTP.

 

 

 

 

 


Build Side-by-Side UI Extensibility with SAP Build Apps

SAP Build Apps enables developers to implement loosely coupled extension applications securely on top of the existing SAP solution they already have. SAP Build Apps provides drag-and-drop capabilities for Citizen developers to build enterprise-grade applications confidently, authenticate and access SAP Business Technology Platform destinations. You can preview your SAP Build Apps project as web preview and can build it to deploy on SAP Build Work Zone or Android/IOS.

Here you will learn how to use SAP Build Apps, create an app that performs all the CRU (Create, Read, Update) operations for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud BONUSPLAN API for managing the Bonus Plan for the employee.

The point of this tutorial is to show you how you would perform all the CRU (Create, Read, Update) operations, and how you would handle some of the complexities of the SAP backend APIs (e.g. strict requirements for the data and handle multiple determination) for the Bonus plan scenario.

You will create an app with 2 pages:

  • Page 1: Display all Bonus plans
  • Page 2: Manage Bonus Plan, which handles Create or Update the bonus plan for employees.

Create destination to SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.   

In the SAP BTP cockpit, as administrator you need to create a destination to enable the communication to the S/4HANA Cloud system. In addition, the destination must be enabled for use in SAP Build Apps.

Procedure:

In the SAP BTP cockpit, navigate to your subaccount.

Choose Connectivity > Destination > Create Destination.

Choose Blank Template and enter the following data and click on Save.

Field

Value

Name

Enter the destination name.

Type

Select HTTP.

Description

Enter a description (SAP Build Apps to ABAP Callback Destination)

URL

Enter the Service URL saved during Communication Arrangement creation. If not saved access the communication arrangement

Proxy Type

Internet

Authentication

Select BasicAuthentication.

User

(Inbound) communication user used in the communication arrangement

Password

Set the password to the secret. Password of the (inbound) communication user used in the communication arrangement.

Additional Properties

Add the following properties:

‚ÄúBuildApps.RequiresCsrf‚Äù ‚Üí true

‚ÄúAppgyverEnabled‚Äù ‚Üí true

‚ÄúHTML5.DynamicDestination ‚Äù ‚Üí true

Save your entries.

 

 

 

 

 

 


Open SAP Build Apps

Open SAP Build Apps, by going to the SAP BTP cockpit, and under Instances and Subscriptions, click SAP Build Apps.

 

In the lobby of your SAP Build Apps, click Create.

 

Select Application.

 

Select Frontend and followed by this Select Web & Mobile Application and press Next button. Please note that the user needs to have access to the Custom Identity Provider to be able to create a Web & Mobile Application.

For the project name, enter Bonus plan Management and description as ‚ÄúExtend a key user extension from S/4HANA Cloud public edition ‚Äúthen click Create.

 

Connect to the REST API from the Custom Business Object on S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

In this step, you will make a connection to the BONUSPLAN API of your SAP S/4HANA Cloud system. You will enable entities: BONUSPLAN (the header for a BONUSPLAN)

  1. Go to the Integrations tab.
  2. Click Add Integration.
  3. Click BTP Destinations, and then select the destination to your SAP S/4HANA Cloud BONUSPLAN API which you have created in ‚ÄúCreate destination to SAP S/4HANA Cloud system‚Äù section.
  4. Select Click Install Integration (upper right).
  5. Under Data Entities, scroll down so you can see both YY1_BONUSPLAN and I_Currency. For each, select it and click Enable Data Entity.
  6. You can now select an entity and click Browse Real Data to see live data from SAP S/4HANA Cloud.


  7. Click Save (upper right).



Create page for displaying BONUSPLANs (Homepage)

Now you will create the home page that displays a list of Bonus Plans, for which the user can update the existing Bonus Plan and can create a new Bonus Plan.

  • You will already have a Home Page. Click on it.
  • Click Variables ‚Üí Data Variables and create a data variable based on YY1_BONUSPLAN.

 

  • Click the User Interface tab to return to the UI canvas. 
  • Add a Title field and a Text field. Set the content for the text component as ‚ÄúBonus plan details‚Äù and add a button with value ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù value and list item component.


 

 

  • Add a List Item component

 

  • Click the list item, and configure its properties as follows:

Property

Value

Repeat with

data variable YY1_BONUSPLAN1

Primary label

data item in repeat current.EmployeeName

Secondary label

data item in repeat current.EmployeeID

 

Now you can test the application which should display the Bonus list by saving your changes and clicking on Preview to preview the application.

Hopefully you got this far and found success! Congratulations!!!

 

You will define the logic for the list item selection later once we finish next step (Create page for Manage Bonus Plan)

  • With the list item selected, open the logic canvas.
  • Add an Open page flow function, and configure it as follows:

Property

Value

Page

Manage Bonus Plan

Parameters ‚Üí SAP_UUID

data item in repeat current.SAP_UUID

Parameters ‚Üí EmployeeName

data item in repeat current. EmployeeName

 


You will define the logic for the Button later once we finish next step (Create page for Manage Bonus Plan)

  • Drag and drop an Open page flow function, and configure it as follows: Make sure that don‚Äôt bind any value to the page parameter of Manage Bonus Plan and Page value as ‚ÄúManage Bonus Plan‚Äù.


Create page for Manage Bonus Plan

You will create a page for Manage Bonus Plan.

  • Click Add New Page, enter Manage Bonus Plan, and click OK.
  • Navigate to page Manage Bonus Plan
  • Click PAGE PARAMETERS and two parameter such as EmployeeName of type Text and SAP_UUID of type UUID.

 

 

  • Click Data Variables and create a variable for YY1_BONUSPLAN and Data Variable Type as ‚ÄúSingle data record‚Äù and bind SAP_UUID value to the page parameter SAP_UUID.

 

 

  • Click View to return to the UI canvas and remove all the default components.
  • Add the following components in this order:
    • Title1
    • Text1
    • Title2
    • Container 1, and inside the container add
      • Input Field
      • CheckBox Field
  • Date field with input1(Date field can be installed from the marketplace if its not available by default)
  • Date field with input2
  • Container 2, and inside the container add          
        • Input Field1
        • Input Field2
  • Container 3, and inside the container add          
        • Input Field1
        • Input Field2
  • Container 4, and inside the container add          
        • Input Field1
        • Input Field2
  • Container 5, and inside the container add
        • Input Field1
        • Dropdown Field2
  • Button
  • Configure the following components:

Component

Property

Value

Title1

Content

Bonus plan

Text1

Content with formula

"Bonus plan for " +  IF(NOT(IS_NULLY(params.EmployeeName)), params.EmployeeName, "")

Title2

Content

General Information

Container 1

Layout

Horizontal

¬∑ Input field

Value

With Data Variable YY1_BONUSPLAN1.ID

 

Label

ID

¬∑ CheckBox

Value

With Data Variable YY1_BONUSPLAN1.IsConsistent

 

Label

Is Consistent

Date field with input1

Label

Validity Start Date

 

Placeholder Text with Formula

FORMAT_DATETIME_LOCAL(DATETIME(NUMBER(SUBSTRING(data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.ValidityStartDate, 6,19))), "YYYY.MM.DD")

 

Date field with input2

Label

Validity End Date

 

Placeholder Text with Formula

FORMAT_DATETIME_LOCAL(DATETIME(NUMBER(SUBSTRING(data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.ValidityEndDate, 6,19))), "YYYY.MM.DD")

Container 2

Layout

Horizontal

¬∑ Input field2

Value

With Data Variable YY1_BONUSPLAN1.LowBonusAssignmentFactor

 

Label

Low Bonus Assignment Factor

¬∑ Input field2

Value

With Data Variable YY1_BONUSPLAN1.HighBonusAssignmentFactor

 

Label

High Bonus Assignment Factor

Container 3

Layout

Horizontal

¬∑ Input field1

Value

With Data Variable YY1_BONUSPLAN1.LowBonusPercentage_V

 

Label

Low Bonus Percentage

¬∑ Input field2

Value

With Data Variable YY1_BONUSPLAN1.HighBonusPercentage_V

 

Label

High Bonus Percentage

Container 4

Layout

Horizontal

¬∑ Input field 1

Value

With Data Variable YY1_BONUSPLAN1.EmployeeID

 

Label

Employee ID

¬∑ Input field 2

Value

With Data Variable YY1_BONUSPLAN1.EmployeeName

 

Label

Employee Name

Container 5

Layout

Horizontal

¬∑ Input field 1

Value

With Data Variable YY1_BONUSPLAN1.TargetAmount_V

 

Label

Target Amount

¬∑ Dropdown field1

Option list
With formula

MAP(data.I_Currency1, {label: item.Currency +"("+ item.Currency_Text+")", value: item.Currency})

 

Selected Value

With Data Variable  YY1_BONUSPLAN1.TargetAmount_C

 

Label

Currency

Button

Label

Save

 

Add logic to Add/Update Bonus Plan:

  1. Now we will add the logic to the Save button. To achieve this, click on Save button and open its logic canvas.
  2. Add logic flow functions and connect them as in the following:
  3. Configure the flow functions as follows:
  • IF condition (first): Set the condition to the following formula (validates the SAP_UUID field):
    NOT(IS_NULLY(params.SAP_UUID))

Update record: Set the following:

  • Resource name: YY1_BONUSPLAN1
  • Risk ID: page parameter SAP_UUID
  • Record: Set the following formula (allows us to make sure the integer fields receive a number value):

{ ValidityStartDate: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.ValidityStartDate, ValidityEndDate: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.ValidityEndDate,LowBonusAssignmentFactor: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.LowBonusAssignmentFactor,HighBonusAssignmentFactor:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.HighBonusAssignmentFactor,LowBonusPercentage_V: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.LowBonusPercentage_V, HighBonusPercentage_V:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.HighBonusPercentage_V, EmployeeID: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.EmployeeID,  EmployeeName: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.EmployeeName, TargetAmount_V:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.TargetAmount_V, TargetAmount_C:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.TargetAmount_C}

 

Create record: Set the following:

  • Resource name: YY1_BONUSPLAN1
  • Record: Set the following formula:

{ SAP_UUID: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.SAP_UUID, ValidityStartDate: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.ValidityStartDate, ValidityEndDate: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.ValidityEndDate,LowBonusAssignmentFactor: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.LowBonusAssignmentFactor,HighBonusAssignmentFactor:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.HighBonusAssignmentFactor,LowBonusPercentage_V: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.LowBonusPercentage_V, HighBonusPercentage_V:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.HighBonusPercentage_V, EmployeeID: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.EmployeeID,  EmployeeName: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.EmployeeName, TargetAmount_V:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.TargetAmount_V, TargetAmount_C:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.TargetAmount_C}

 

You can set the Toast and Alert flow functions for both Create record and Update record with the appropriate Text message to inform the user about the success or error message during Save.

Now you can now test the application, which is designed to display all available Bonus plans. If you select an existing Bonus Plan, the system will load all relevant field values for the chosen employee, allowing you to update those details. Additionally, you can create a new Bonus Plan by using the Create button and by following the steps mentioned in the section Test app.

Thanks, you have completed SAP Build Apps application development by extending a Custom Business Object successfully! üòäCongratulations!!!

Test app

  • Open the Preview Portal using the Preview button located in the top-right corner.
  • Go to the Launch tab, then Open Preview Portal, then Web Preview.

 

  • Click Bonus Plan to open the app. You should see the first page with a list of Bonus Plan in the first page and while navigating to the Manage Bonus Plan page handles Create or Update the bonus plan for employees.

For Deploying an app created with SAP Build Apps to HTML5 applications repository on SAP BTP and Integrate an SAP Build Apps application into SAP Build Work Zone, please do refer to this tutorial.

entry.title: Custom Journal Entry Query by G/L and Cost Center in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, reporting on Journal Entries often requires not only grouping by GL Accounts but also breaking down the information based on Cost Centers. This can be critical for department-level spend control or management reporting where even costs on the same account need to be analyzed separately.

In this blog post, I will show how to create a Custom Analytical Query that splits entries on the same GL account into separate rows based on Cost Center.

Use case

We want to analyze expenses posted to G/L account 61400000 ("Training and Education") across multiple cost centers. Although the same account is used, it is important to distinguish which department owns the expense.

 
Journal EntryG/L AccountAmountCost CenterCost Center Description
10000012361400000500HR001HR Department
10000012461400000300IT002IT Department
10000012561400000700SALES003Sales Department

Prerequisites

Ensure your user has the following roles assigned:

Business RoleBusiness Role ID
Analytics SpecialistSAP_BR_EXTENSIBILITY_SPEC
General Ledger AccountantSAP_BR_GL_ACCOUNTANT
 
If you don‚Äôt have the necessary roles, please contact your administrator or refer to the Maintain Business Users app.

Implementation

To implement the custom query, you‚Äôll create a new Custom Analytical Query in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition based on the standard data source I_JournalEntryItemCube.

Within the query, you‚Äôll define Restricted Structure Elements to represent specific combinations of G/L Accounts and Cost Centers. This allows you to display postings to the same account in separate rows depending on the cost center dimension. If required, you can further build a –°ustom Report or Fiori tile on top of the query for easier access and integration into business users' daily activities.

1. Open the Custom Analytical Queries app (F1572)

Click "Create"

2. Create a Custom Analytical Query

In the opened window, set the Query Name (for example, CUSTOMREPORT), Data Source (I_JOURNALENTRYITEMCUBE) and select "OK".

To implement the custom report, you‚Äôll create a new Custom Analytical Query in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition based on the standard data source I_JournalEntryItemCube.

3. Fill in the parameters in the "General" tab

The General window is used to configure the main properties of a custom analytical query. It provides key settings that define the query's behavior, metadata, and runtime characteristics.

  • Label ‚Äì name for the query that will be displayed in the system (e.g. CUSTOMREPORT)
  • Processing Effort ‚Äì allows prioritization of query performance (e.g. High)
  • Runtime Extensibility ‚Äì a checkbox indicating whether runtime extensibility is enabled for the query.
  • Handling  ‚Äì specifies how zero values in the query results are handled (e.g. None)
  • Hide on Axis ‚Äì determines whether zero-suppressed rows or columns are hidden (e.g. Rows & Columns)

After filling in the fields, navigate to the Field Selection tab.

4. Define the fields in the "Field Selection" tab

The "Field Selection" window is used to define the fields included in the query and specify how they are positioned in the query output (e.g., as rows, columns, or free fields). This setup controls the structure and content of the query results.

Available Fields ‚Äì displays a list of all fields available from the query's data source.

  • Selected Fields ‚Äì shows the fields that have been added to the query.
  • Row ‚Äì fields added to this section will define the row structure of the query results.
  • Column ‚Äì fields added to this section define the column structure of the query results.
  • Free ‚Äì fields in this section are not directly displayed in the query results but are available for filtering or grouping during query execution.

Selected Fields ‚Äì displays the fields that have been added to the query. It includes fields selected from the Available Fields section and organizes them into Row, Column, Measure Structure, or Free, depending on their role in the report layout.

After selecting the fields, navigate to the Display tab.

5. Define the fields in the "Display" tab

The "Display" window is used to configure the layout and behavior of fields in the query output. It allows users to determine which fields appear as rows, columns, or free fields, as well as customize properties such as display options, sorting, and formatting. Fields can be reassigned between Row, Column, and Free using either drag-and-drop or the Axis property in the Properties panel or Up, Down, Add buttons.

To enhance your report logic, additional elements can be added via the Add button:

  • Add Restricted Measure ‚Äì creates a key figure with a predefined filter condition (e.g., only for a specific company code or fiscal year).
  • Add Calculated Measure ‚Äì defines new key figures based on arithmetic or logical operations involving existing ones.
  • Add Converted Measure ‚Äì generates a key figure with unit conversion applied (e.g., currency or quantity unit).
  • Add Counter ‚Äì introduces a counter that increments for each record, which is useful for record numbering or counting occurrences.
  • Add User Input Filter ‚Äì adds a filter field that prompts the user to enter a value during query execution. This allows for dynamic filtering based on user input.
  • Add Characteristic Structure Element ‚Äì enables more advanced layout or logic customization by defining reusable field structures.

In our example, we will use a Characteristic Structure Element to customize the output view of the query. To add it, —Ålick the Add button and select Add Characteristic Structure Element from the dropdown menu.

In the dialog window that opens, select "OK".

In the Characteristic Structure Element dialog, you can define the properties of the structure element that will be added to your report layout:

  • Label ‚Äì specifies the display name of the structure element, which will appear as a column header in the query result (e.g., 1.1. HR Expenses).
  • Name ‚Äì provides a unique technical identifier for the structure element used internally within the query (e.g., HRExpenses).
  • Structure Element ‚Äì determines the type of structure element to create:
    • Restricted Structure Element ‚Äì aggregates data based on predefined filter criteria (e.g., specific G/L account and cost center).
    • Calculated Structure Element ‚Äì creates a key figure based on calculations involving other structure elements (e.g., differences, percentages).

In our example, we select Restricted Structure Element to isolate and display values that match specific filtering conditions.

Once the settings are defined, click OK to proceed.

6. Define Characteristic Structure Elements

Once the Characteristic Structure Element has been added, it appears in the Row section of the Display tab. On the right-hand side of the screen, the Properties allows further customization:

  • Label ‚Äì choose between a static label (manually defined) or a dynamic label (generated based on logic or field values). In our example, the element is Static.
  • Name ‚Äì the technical identifier for internal use in query logic.
  • Display ‚Äì enables or disables visibility of the element in the report output.
  • Decimals ‚Äì defines the number of decimal places shown in the report output.
  • Scaling ‚Äì allows automatic scaling of numerical values (e.g., thousands, millions).
  • Reverse Sign ‚Äì reverses the sign of key figure values, often used to display credits as negatives.

Hierarchy ‚Äì controls how the element behaves in a hierarchical display:

  • Collapsed ‚Äì when enabled, the hierarchy node is shown collapsed by default, hiding its children until expanded by the user.
  • Enable Hierarchy ‚Äì activates the hierarchy mode for the element, allowing parent-child relationships to be displayed. 
  • Parent ‚Äì specifies the parent node for the current element when hierarchy mode is active.

Collision Handling ‚Äì defines how formatting and calculation settings are applied when different definitions conflict:

  • Formula ‚Äì determines whether the formula from the current element or from the collision source takes precedence.
  • Decimal ‚Äì specifies which decimal setting  should be applied in case of conflict.
  • Scaling ‚Äì specifies which scaling factor should be applied in case of conflict.

In the Fixed Values section at the bottom, you can define restrictions that determine which data is included in the structure element. In this case, a fixed filter is applied on the Account Assignment field using the Include option. This filter is the core of the Restricted Structure Element, as it ensures that only relevant records (e.g., for a specific G/L account and cost center) are used in calculations.

To refine the restriction criteria, click Add Restriction. You can specify multiple conditions based on various dimensions, such as G/L Account, Cost Center, or Functional Area.

In the Dimensions window, select the G/L Account field.


On the Include tab, select the "=" operator and define the account 61400000.

Similarly, define the restriction for cost center HR001.
To remove an unnecessary restriction (for example,  Account Assignment), select the Remove Restriction function.

Similarly, define the Characteristic Structure Element for 1.2. IT Expenses (account 61400000, cost center IT002) and 1.3. Sales Expenses (account 61400000, cost center SALES003).

To add a node, select Add Characteristic Structure Element and define the Label, Name, and Structure Element (Calculated Structure Element).
To define a summation formula for the previously created expense rows, go to the Expression section and click Edit.
Define the formula using mathematical operators and the list of available measures.
To define the created node as hierarchical, go to the previously created expense rows, check Enable Hierarchy in the Hierarchy section, and specify the parent node.

7. Define the fields in the "Filters" tab

The Filters tab is used to define the selection criteria that control which data is displayed in the report or structure. Filters help limit the dataset to the relevant scope by specifying fixed values, allowing user input during execution, or leaving the field unrestricted.

For the selected fields, you can define the following filter settings:

  • No filters ‚Äì allows all values; no restriction applied.
  • Fixed Values ‚Äì choosing fixed values defines a permanent filter value. End users cannot reconfigure this value. You can specify:
    • Include ‚Äì values that must be included in the dataset.
    • Exclude ‚Äì values that must be excluded from the dataset
  • User Input Values ‚Äì upon query execution, this option enables end users to choose a value that filters the result set. The following settings are possible for User Input Values:
    • Selection Type ‚Äì this option enables you to enter a single value, a value range, or a hierarchy node option to define the filter condition. The hierarchy node option appears only if a field supports a hierarchy. And the hierarchy node option displays the hierarchy tree in the User Input Filter screen.
    • Multiple Selection (checkbox) ‚Äì this option enables the end user to choose multiple values as input during query execution.
    • Mandatory (checkbox) ‚Äì this option ensures that the end user must make an entry.
    • Variable Sequence ‚Äì this option enables you to maintain the order of the parameter. During execution, the fields with variable sequence defined will take the first priority to the fields that have no value maintained for the same.
    • Default Value ‚Äì the value that you enter in this field appears in the User Input Value field and is displayed to the end user.
  • Derivation Functions ‚Äì this option enables automatically derive the filter value based on predefined logic or relationships with other fields. 
    • Lookup Entity ‚Äì defines the source for value help assistance for the field. This could be a CDS view, master data table, or other value provider.
    • Hide (checkbox) ‚Äì when selected, the field will not be displayed to the end user in the filter selection screen, but any fixed value or derivation logic applied to it will still be active during query execution.
    • Mandatory (checkbox) ‚Äì ensures that the filter must be provided before the query can be executed.

After defining all parameters (for example, Company Code, Ledger, Fiscal Year, Fiscal Period), you can save the draft of your Custom Analytical Query by selecting the Save Draft option. After saving, you can preview the custom query by selecting the Preview option.

In the window that opens, you will see a preview of your query.

After reviewing the query, you can return to the previous window and publish the Custom Analytical Query by clicking the Publish button.

After the query is successfully published, its status will change to Published.

Summary
In this blog post, we created a custom journal entry query by G/L account and cost center in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition.

We walked through the process of designing the query, configuring parameters and input options, previewing the results, and publishing it for use.

Once published, this query can serve as a powerful reporting tool, or act as a data source for custom applications, enabling more targeted financial insights.

Let me know if you‚Äôve implemented similar custom analytical queries!

entry.title: How to find CDS views in S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition
entry.content:
TLDR

With 3-tier S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition you can now connect your ABAP Developer Tools (ADT, in Eclipse) directly to the system.  You can browse development objects including CDS views. Creating an ABAP Repository Tree allows you to browse by component and release status, to find released views to use in your extensions

Remind me, what is S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition?

S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition (or Public CE) is SAP's SaaS ERP. Formerly known as S/4HANA Cloud, and as S/4HANA Public Cloud, this flavour of S/4 emphasises a tight fit to standard business processes.  The solution is hosted and managed by SAP. Only clean-core extensions are possible and upgrades happen according to a published schedule

Why does S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition matter?

Whilst the largest customers tend to draw most of the limelight in the SAP world, there are only so many of them.  As you widen your gaze to include progressively smaller and smaller customers their number increases more than proportionately.  In other words there are a lot more companies with 10,000 employees that there are with 100,000 employees.  There are a heck of a lot more companies with 1000 employees that there are with 10,000. This means that the total market is huge, even if each individual subscription is smaller

Ceteris paribus, these smaller customers are more likely to go for Public CE, because it can be more cost effective for them.  Indeed the inability to perform 'dirty' extensions & enhancements, and the inability to stay on a outdated release can be seen as advantages of Public CE.  SAP's vision is that over time more and more customers will switch to Public CE, some after 'cleaning up' their legacy enhancements.  They hope that, over time, larger and larger customers will sign up

How can we extend S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition?

Whilst a fit to standard processes is the goal, Public CE can be extended and enhanced if needed.  There might be a small variation to fit a competitive advantage that that particular customer has, their 'special sauce' if you like.  Historically these extensions could be categorised as

  1. On-stack key-user extensions

  2. Side-by-side developer-built extensions on BTP

To support the latter type we expose data via the SAP-standard published APIs, by creating custom CDS views or by creating custom business objects with a back-end service enabled. Events can also trigger extensions on BTP

Why are released views precious?

To expose standard data that isn't part of a published API we must (if 2-tier) use the custom CDS view option. We can only use released views as sources, and only a fraction of views are released.  Why is that?  Well, releasing a view is a big deal for SAP because it represents a promise to keep that view available and up to date.  If this wasn't the case our extensions could break every upgrade cycle, as standard views or fields on standard views were removed.  This would limit the viability of Public CE altogether 

Hence finding released views with the right data is an important part of extension design.  Happily, that task is getting easier, with the increased prevalence of the 3-tier landscape with Public CE

Why are 3 tiers better than 2?

When my first customer went live with Public CE in 2019 all setups had Test and Prod environments only.  Having a background at big on-prem customers, with their 5 or 6 tier landscapes (e.g. Sandbox / Dev / Test / Pre-Prod / Prod / Training) I found this pretty scary!

Now all new Public CE customers get 3 tiers ( Dev / Test / Prod ) and existing customers are being migrated.  The Dev environment has 2 tenants, for development and for customizing. Under the hood, these represent client 80 and client 100. This facilitates the introduction of a new enhancement technique.  Using the embedded ABAP Cloud environment we can use RAP (the ABAP Restful Programming Model) to build OData services. This gives far greater flexibility that we get building custom CDS views in a Fiori app (as a 'key-user')

This on-stack extensibility was known for a while as Embedded Steampunk

Of course, finding released CDS views is still important, because ABAP cloud will only allow us to use released CDS views as data sources. So what's the best way to find them?

What's the best way to find released CDS views in a 3-tier Public CE landscape?

Once you've connected your ABAP Development Tools to your S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition system (development tenant/client 80) you can browse all of the development objects.  This is something that just wasn't possible before, because we were limited to what we could see in various Fiori apps

If you try to browse all of the CDS views, you will likely hit an issue as there are just too many to be rendered.  I recommend instead building your own ABAP Repository Tree (via File->New).

On the first screen (of the repo tree wizard) select Core Data Services

On the next screen, in the Selected Tree Levels, remove package from level 3, and replace it with Application Component.  Then select drag the API State level over to level 4.

Click Finish. Now, in the tree, you can open Core Data Services, Data Definitions and then the component of your choice.  The released views are found under USE_IN_CLOUD_DEVELOPMENT. You can open the individual view to see the definition.

You can confirm that the view is released by considering the API State tab in the properties, on the bottom right of your Eclipse screen. C1 Use System Internally is the key part.  If it is Released you should be able to use this view in a custom CDS view or in RAP development

Because you are connected to your dev system you can see the release status of every view which is available on your current release

What do you think?

Are you an expert on extensions already?  Or are you surprised at how much scope there is for extension on S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition?  Extensions certainly got a little easier, now that we can see every view available. Let me know in the comments what you think, and if you have any tips for finding views

I would love to find a good way to find CDS views which use a given table as a source (directly or indirectly).  This can be done in the View Browser app, but we won't see all of the views. Perhaps in future SAP could support using the where-used feature in ADT

entry.content:

entry.title: First Experiences GenAI-driven extensibility assistant for Custom Fields and Custom Logic app
entry.content:
These are my first experiences with the extensibility assistant

Use within Custom Fields:


You can call the extensibility assistant in the Custom Fields app start screen, and in the details screen of a single custom field.

Calling the extensibility assistant in the start screen:

Example Prompt :Create a Z field in the Journal Entry Item Level , Field Name : Reference1 and Field Description : Reference 1_HD , Data Type : Char/Text Field Length : 20 and Enable it for the RAP BO I_JOURNALENTRYTP

In the initial screen of the Custom Fields app on the button bar at the top right of the custom field list, you'll find a open assistant button. 

Enter the prompt it will preselect Business context

 After selecting the right context accept the proposal from SAP it will create the field and enable to edit for detail screen 

Calling the extensibility assistant in the details screen:

  • On the button bar at the bottom of the screen, you'll find the diamond button.

  • if you want to ask about a custom field displayed on the details screen, you can refer to it using expressions like ‚Äúthis field‚Äù. A common use case is seeking assistance to expose the field through an OData service, UI, CDS view, or SOAP API.

  • Once selected Press save and publish manually . As you see from the below the field is automatically extended in the SOAP API section based on the prompt .

 

Use within Custom Logic:

  • Start the extensibility assistant in the Custom Logic app by clicking the Open Assistant button on the implementations table toolbar

 

  •  The extensibility assistant will show a list of BAdIs that fit your request or a message if no BAdIs were found. 

Select and create implementation . This will only help to find right BADIs not generation of the coding in the BADI üôÇ
